questions.text: A baby was born in a hospital, declared stillborn by staff, but the parents believe the baby was born alive and accuse the hospital of causing death. As a forensic pathologist, what key findings would suggest that the baby was alive at birth?

choices.text: Presence of gelatinous tissue in ear

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, presence of soft spongy lungs suggests the baby was alive at birth. When a baby is born alive and takes its first breaths, the lungs fill with air, making them soft and spongy. Lungs in stillbirth are usually dense and firm.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat, 1-2cm less than the abdominal circumference Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70 of body weight 1/35 of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040-1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sink in water Contains mucin and air. Floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue

Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is seen in the condition affecting the child shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image of a child showing dark peeling patches over edematous limbs (flaky paint dermatosis) points to the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. The child will have a flag sign. 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterised by oedema. The oedema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalised oedema, affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). Other signs of kwashiorkor are skin changes, which typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled, peeling patches with pale skin underneath that is easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. Alternate bands of hypopigmented and normally pigmented hair patterns are seen when the growth occurs in spurts, known as flag sign. Children with oedema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Simian or monkey facies and loose, wrinkled skin, with marked wasting of fat and muscle, are characteristic features of marasmus. The eyes may be sunken from loss of retro-orbital fat.

questions.text:
A middle-aged female presents to the gynaecological OPD with a history of lower abdominal pain, fever and vaginal discharge. She gives a history of long-term usage of IUD. The cytological finding of the discharge shows the following finding. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?

IUD- Intra-uterine device
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with associated long-term IUD use and the cytological findings of clumps of ink blot or cotton wool-like filamentous organisms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease by actinomyces, and the drug of choice is intravenous penicillin.

The most common aetiological agent is Actinomyces israeli, which is a gram-positive, anaerobic, filamentous, non-acid, fast bacilli. High-dose parenteral Penicillin G or amoxicillin for 4-6 weeks, followed by oral Penicillin V for 6- 12 months, is the treatment of pelvic actinomyces.

Actinomyces is commonly found in the vaginal flora of IUD users. An increase in duration of use increases the colonisation causing chronic PID presenting as lower abdominal pain, fever, vaginal discharge, bleeding and weight loss.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with one week history of fever, joint pain and myalgia. The examination findings are shown below. The patient has been on procainamide for arrhythmia. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing malar rash are suggestive of features of lupus in a patient who is on procainamide, suggestive of a diagnosis of drug-induced lupus. Drug-induced lupus is commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies.

Drug-induced lupus (DIL) is associated with symptoms such as fever, arthralgia and myalgia, serositis and rash during therapy with certain medications and biological agents. It differs from SLE in that it has lesser female predilection, rarely involves the kidney or the brain, and is not associated with anti-dsDNA antibodies (option B). DIL is commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies. The most frequent drugs which can cause drug-induced lupus are:

  • Antiarrhythmics like procainamide, disopyramide, and propafenone
  • Hydralazine
  • Propylthiouracil
  • Antipsychotics like chlorpromazine and lithium
  • Antiepileptics like carbamazepine and phenytoin 
  • Isoniazid
  • Biologics which block IFNs and TNF

In DIL, ANA becomes positive before the appearance of symptoms. However, even patients who have positive ANA after being on therapy with one of these drugs might never develop clinical features of DIL. DIL resolves over several weeks once the offending agent is stopped.

Anti-centromere antibodies (option A) are seen in CREST syndrome while anti-U1 RNP (option D) are seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient suffers from a myocardial infarction. Laboratory investigations reveal that troponin is elevated as a result of myocardial cell death. Which of the following features would not be seen in the cells of this patient?
questions.solution:
The manner of cell death seen in a patient with myocardial infarction is necrosis. Cell shrinkage is seen in apoptosis. 

Necrosis occurs due to severe injury. It can occur due to ischemia, exposure to toxins, burns, chemical and physical injury, and conditions that cause proteases to leak out of cells and damage the surrounding tissue. 

It is characterized by denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, enzymatic digestion of the cell. 

Necrosis occurs when damage to the cell is severe and irreversible. This leads to the entrance of lysosomal enzymes into the cytoplasm causing digestion. The contents of the cells may also enter the extracellular space and damage the surrounding tissue via inflammation. 

Some molecules called damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) such as ATP, uric acid that is present within healthy cells but are released during severe cell injury. These molecules trigger macrophages leading to phagocytosis of debris and the production of inflammatory cytokines. 

Necrosis can lead to the leakage of intracellular proteins into the circulation. These proteins can be detected as part of diagnostic tests for specific organ injuries. Examples include troponins for cardiac cell death, alkaline phosphatase for bile duct epithelium, and transaminases for hepatocytes. 

Some morphological features of necrosis are as follows: 

  • Nuclear changes following one of three patterns:
    • Karyolysis - decreased basophilic nature of chromatin due to enzymatic degradation of DNA by endonucleases
    • Pyknosis - nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia
    • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Increase eosinophilia
  • Glassy homogenous appearance of the cell due to loss of glycogen
  • Myelin figures replacing dead cells that get further degraded
  • Discontinuities in plasma, organelle membranes
  • Dilation of mitochondria

The nucleus disappears within 1-2 days.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a history of diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 2 months. Investigations show increased T3 and T4 levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She undergoes fine needle aspiration cytology which is shown in the image below. Which of the following findings are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hashitoxicosis, a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis that usually occurs in the first two months of Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Hürthle cells are seen in fine-needle aspiration in this condition.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is more commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. In the majority of cases, it is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse and symmetrical enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. Microscopic features include:

  • Extensive lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers
  • Hürthle cells, are epithelial cells that line atrophied thyroid follicles and contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm

The image below shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

In most cases, there is a gradual development of hypothyroidism. However, in some patients, transient thyrotoxicosis may occur due to the release of thyroid hormones from disrupted thyroid follicles known as hashitoxicosis. Free T4 and T3 levels are elevated and TSH and radioactive iodine uptake are decreased in this phase. As hypothyroidism occurs, T4 and T3 levels fall, and TSH increases. Patients are also more susceptible to developing other autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus.  

Other options:

Options B and C: Orphan Annie Eye nuclei (nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and a ground-glass appearance) and pseudo-inclusions (nuclear membrane grooves) are characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is the most common form of thyroid cancer. Other histological hallmarks include branching papillae covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cell and psammoma bodies (concentrically calcified structures within the papillae). This type of cancer has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in 95% of cases.

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells are found in granulomatous thyroiditis. Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain thyroiditis, occurs due to viral infection, most often upper respiratory tract infection. The virus destroys thyroid follicles, inciting cytotoxic T lymphocyte reaction against the thyroid antigens. Thyroid pain is the most common symptom. In some cases, there may be transient thyrotoxicosis lasting for 2-6 weeks. Normal function returns after recovery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was brought to the emergency room in a lethargic stage. He has a history of consumption of around 250 mL of alcohol daily for the last 30 years. The following test was performed on him: he took a minute to join all the dots. Suspecting a neurological condition, which of the following is not likely to precipitate it
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is a number connection test to assess hepatic encephalopathy (HE). Hepatic encephalopathy is suspected if he is unable to connect the dots from 1 to 25 within 30 seconds. Hyperkalaemia is least likely to precipitate hepatic encephalopathy.

HE occurs when the liver fails to metabolise the nitrogenous substances produced by the gut bacteria which it normally metabolises. These toxins cross the blood-brain barrier and cause CNS manifestations. 
Some factors precipitate hepatic encephalopathy:

  • Hypokalemia- increases tubular ammonia production, reduces hepatic elimination, and facilitates entry of ammonia into the blood-brain barrier.
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding – bleeding increases blood ammonia level
  • Dehydration- diuretic use, paracentesis, diarrhoea 
  • Infections- immunological response to infections leads to cerebral oedema
  • Constipation- an increase in orofecal transit time leads to increased reabsorption of toxic metabolites in the gut.

Below is an image of a number connection test consisting of randomly placed 25 numbered circles. A normal individual can connect the dots from 1 to 25 within 30 seconds. A patient with hepatic encephalopathy takes longer than 30 seconds, and the grading is done according to the time taken to join the numbers. The test should be stopped if a patient takes more than 2 minutes. 

Related Pearl: Precipitating factors of Hepatic Encephalopathy

Common precipitating factors of Hepatic Encephalopathy are:

  • Increased Nitrogen load:
    • GI bleeding
    • Excess dietary protein
    • Azotemia
    • Constipation
  • Drugs
    • Narcotics
    • Sedatives
    • Excess diuretics
  • Electrolytic imbalance:
    • Hypokalemia
    • Alkalosis
    • Hypoxia
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hypovolemia
  • Miscellaneous
    • Infection
    • Surgery
    • Superimposed liver disease
    • Shunts

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management protocols, which of the following colored bins should the instrument shown below be discarded in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dynamic hip screw and it should be discarded in the blue colored bin.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue bin. Metallic sharps (scalpels, blades, needles, etc) are discarded in white or translucent bins.

Other options:

Option A: White (translucent) containers are puncture-proof and leakproof. It is used for the disposal of waste sharps including metals.

Option C: Yellow containers are lined with yellow non-chlorinated plastic bags. It is used for the disposal of anatomical wastes, discarded medicines, and clinical laboratory waste.

Option D: Red containers are lined with red non-chlorinated bags. Recyclable contaminated waste such as intravenous tubes, catheters, and urine bags are discarded in these containers. 

The following image shows the various logos signifying specific types of wastes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with major depression 3 years back has been on long-term therapy with antidepressants. She comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of reduced libido and difficulty in attaining orgasm. Which of the following drugs is she most likely consuming?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a woman on long-term antidepressant therapy developing sexual dysfunction is most likely to have been caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Sertraline is the SSRI among the given options.

All SSRIs cause sexual dysfunction, and it is the most common adverse effect of SSRIs associated with long-term treatment. Presenting adverse effects include anorgasmia, inhibited orgasm, and decreased libido. Other side effects of SSRIs include the following:

Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal (5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, diarrhoea, anorexia, vomiting, flatulence, and dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, seizures, emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, constipation, sedation
Cardiovascular Drug-induced long QT syndrome
Haematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, galactorrhea

Other options: 

Option A - Moclobemide is a selective, reversible inhibitor of monoamine oxidase (a) (RIMAs), the most common adverse effects of which are dizziness, nausea, insomnia, or sleep disturbance. RIMAs cause fewer GI adverse effects than SSRIs, and moclobemide has not been reported to interfere with sexual function.

Option C - Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant. Patients taking this drug do not present with sexual dysfunction. Common side effects include a switch to mania/ hypomania in susceptible patients. Patients also exhibit anticholinergic effects, orthostatic hypotension, sedation, and teratogenicity.

Option D - Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts by increasing both norepinephrine and serotonin. The most common side effects seen in mirtazapine use in the order of decreasing frequency are somnolence, dry mouth, increased appetite, constipation, and weight gain.

questions.text: Which among the following is the characteristic complication associated with chorionic villus sampling?
questions.solution:
Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular hypogenesis are complications associated with chorionic villus sampling.

The best time to perform Chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks.

questions.text: A lady was rushed to the emergency room after consumption of the herbal medicinal juice. She complains of excess salivation, burning pain in the throat, and passing loose stools. On examination, pupils are dilated. The label of the bottle mentions uscharin as an active principle of this plant. Identify the plant.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioned above, along with uscharin as the active principle of this plant, is Calotropis gigantea. 

The active principles of Calotropis gigantea are uscharin, calotropin, calactin, and calotoxin (glycosides).On ingestion, it causes burning throat pain, salivation, vomiting, diarrhoea, stomatitis, mydriasis, and tetanic convulsions, which can eventually lead to collapse and death.

Calotropis gigantea is an organic irritant. it is also called Akdo, Madar rakta arka. The juice of the plant(madar juice) can be used to produce artificial bruises (redness and vesication, when applied to the skin)  introduced into the uterus on an abortion stick for criminal abortion and occasionally used as an arrow poison. The root of Calotropis procera is highly poisonous to cobras and other snakes, which cannot stand even its smell.

Other options:

Option A: The active principles of Semecarpus anacardium are semicarpol and bhilawanol. Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen. Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis due to its local irritant effect.

Option B. Crotin, a toxalbumen is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. when applied to the skin, produces redness, and vesication. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.

Option C: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis (arandi)plant. unbroken seeds are not poisonous. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

The image below shows the seeds of Ricinus communis.

questions.text: A student went to a movie theater. Just before the movie started, an emotional interview of a patient with advanced cancer caused by smoking was played. This is a classic example of:
questions.solution:
The scenario described above is a classical example of health propaganda.

Health propaganda is a strategic communication method designed to influence public attitudes and behaviors toward health, often by using emotional or persuasive tactics. In this case, showing an interview of a dying patient and multiple audio-visuals about the harms of smoking aims to provoke an emotional response and discourage smoking, which is a hallmark of propaganda.

This has to be differentiated from Health education which focuses on providing factual information and knowledge without strong emotions.

Health Education Health propaganda or publicity
Knowledge and skills actively acquired. Knowledge is instilled in the minds of people.
Makes people think for themselves. Prevents or discourages thinking by ready-made slogans.
Develop reflective behavior. Trains people to use judgment before acting Develops reflexive behavior; aims at impulsive actions.
Appeals to reason.
Appeals to emotion.
Develops individuality, personality, and self-expression. Develops a standard pattern of attitudes and behaviors according to the mold used.
The process is behavior centered - aims at developing favorable attitudes, habits, and skills. The process is information-centred - no change of attitude or behavior is designed.

Other options:

Option C: Health promotion encompasses a broader range of activities aimed at improving health and well-being, including policy changes and community initiatives, rather than just using persuasive communication. An example includes something like a "smoke-free" campaign where they can be provided with facilities like counseling, support groups, and workshops about lifestyle changes.

Option D: Health regulation involves legal methods and policies to govern health behaviors and practices, which does not apply to the emotional and awareness-raising approach described. Examples include laws making "warning labels on tobacco products compulsory" which comes under health regulation.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal cramps, rectal bleeding and passage of mucous. The patient’s abdominal radiograph is given below. The patient was started on mesalamine-based therapy. In the presence of which of the following comorbidities will this drug be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario and radiographic features of colonic dilatation with loss of haustral folds are suggestive of toxic megacolon in a case of ulcerative colitis. Mesalamine is a sulfa-drug that causes hemolysis in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and, hence, would be avoided in a patient with G6PD deficiency.

Mesalamine is a sulfasalazine that is given as a prodrug for the treatment of ulcerative colitis and acts via its active metabolite N-acetyl-5-ASA. The most common side effects of sulfasalazine are headache, nausea, fatigue, allergic reactions including rash, fever, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, hepatitis, pneumonitis, hemolytic anaemia, and bone marrow suppression. Most gastrointestinal side effects can be minimised by administering the medication with meals or by titrating the dose. Sulfasalazine inhibits folate absorption in the intestine and, therefore, is usually administered with folate.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man underwent an emergency laparotomy after an RTA. Postoperatively, the following drain was used. Identify the drain used and its type.

RTA - Road traffic accident
questions.solution:
The image shows Robinson’s drain which is a type of non-suctioned, passive closed drain.

It is used to drain the fluid from the abdominal cavity without sucking viscera or omentum based on the mechanism of capillary action, and gravity. The other examples of this type are urinary catheters, nasogastric tubes, etc., 

Drains are broadly classified into two types:

  • Open drains- they are passive, and their drainage is based on gravity by a channel between the body and the external environment. The disadvantages include frequent dressing changes and bacterial contamination. These are useful for debrided wounds and abscess cavities. Penrose drains (option A) and corrugated drains are a few examples of open drains. Below is an image of a penrose drain.
  • Closed drains-
    • Suctioned (active): based on negative pressure for active suctioning and obliterating dead space. Often used after ventral hernia repair, axillary dissections, and head and neck surgeries. E.g., Romovac drain (option B), shown below.
    • Non-suctioned (passive): Robinson drain, Urinary catheter, NG tubes.

Drains are not routinely recommended in all surgeries. Currently, drains are routinely placed in radical and modified neck dissection, parotid surgery, axillary dissection with/without mastectomy, inguinal lymphadenectomy, ventral hernia repair, esophageal surgery, and pancreatic resection.

questions.text:
A young male presents with primary infertility. He gives a history of recurrent chest infections. Semen analysis shows fructose-positive azoospermia. On imaging, a bilateral absence of vas deferens is seen. What will be the most appropriate management?

ICSI- Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection

IUI- Intrauterine Insemination
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and fructose-positive azoospermia indicate cystic fibrosis and congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens (CBAVD). The most appropriate management is testicular sperm extraction with ICSI. 

Fructose-positive azoospermia indicates an obstruction proximal to the seminal vesicle, and cystic fibrosis causing CBAVD is a common cause. Though most obstructive causes are treated surgically, CBAVD is not treatable surgically as there is no cord for reconstruction.

It requires sperm retrieval from the testes or the epididymis via testicular sperm extraction (TESE), percutaneous (PESA), or microsurgical (MESA) epididymal aspiration. This retrieved sperm is then used for ICSI. The cells surrounding the ovum are digested enzymatically and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane. This enables positive pregnancy outcomes in men with azoospermia

Below is an image showing intracytoplasmic sperm injection.

Other options:

Option C- Ovarian hyperstimulation with clomiphene citrate and IUI is done primarily for ovulatory dysfunction, unexplained infertility, male sub-fertility (mild to moderate), and endometriosis. Severe male factor infertility, like CBAVD, may not have a positive outcome.  

Option D- ICSI is preferred over conventional IVF as the sperm count is very poor in CBAVD, and ICSI reduces the risk of low or total failed fertilisation in such cases.

questions.text: Pepsinogen is activated by _________
questions.solution:
Pepsinogen is activated to pepsin by hydrochloric acid.

When pepsinogen is secreted, it has no digestive activity. When it comes in contact with hydrochloric acid, it is activated to form active pepsin. Pepsin is an active proteolytic enzyme at an optimum pH of 1.8-3.5 and is inactivated when it mixes with alkaline intestinal secretions.

It is an active proteolytic enzyme in a highly acidic medium optimum pH 1.8 to 3.5, but above a pH of about 5, it has almost no proteolytic activity and becomes completely inactivated in a short time.

Related Pearl: Classification of proteases

questions.text: Which of the following species of Plasmodium would cause the following pattern of fever in a patient?
questions.solution:
The graph shows a quartan type of fever pattern, characterised by febrile paroxysms occurring every third day, with 72-hour intervals between episodes, which is typically associated with Plasmodium malariae.

Plasmodium malariae is known to cause quartan malaria, where the disease is generally mild, and is notable for its long persistence in the bloodstream at undetectable levels, lasting 50 years or more. Factors like splenectomy or immunosuppression can trigger a recurrence of the infection.

The lifecycle of P. malariae is slower compared to other malaria species, with the development of the parasite taking longer in both humans and mosquitoes. This species is found in tropical Africa, Sri Lanka, Burma, and parts of India, although its distribution is patchy.

These preferentially infect older erythrocytes, and the degree of parasitization is relatively low. The ring forms of the parasite resemble those of P. vivax but are thicker and more intensely stained. Notable features include the presence of band forms, which can stretch across the erythrocyte, and large pigment granules. Erythrocytic schizogony occurs every 72 hours, with mature schizonts releasing approximately 15,000 merozoites.

Gametocytes develop within the internal organs and enter peripheral circulation when fully matured. Male gametocytes exhibit pale blue cytoplasm with a diffuse nucleus, while females display deep blue cytoplasm with a compact nucleus.

The fever patterns observed in different Plasmodium species are depicted below:

Note: Quotidian fever pattern is characterized by fever episodes occurring every 24 hours. Tertian fever pattern features fever episodes that occur every 48 hours. Quartan fever pattern, on the other hand, is marked by fever episodes occurring every 72 hours.

questions.text: The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of ________.
questions.solution:
The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of psoriasis.

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis), and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

questions.text: A male patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. Intraoperative cholangiography shows a complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of ductal length. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The intraoperative cholangiography shows complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of a segment. This is managed with T-tube placement.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Biliary injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy results from failure to define the surgical anatomy owing to visual perceptual error. 

Clinically, patients with post-cholecystectomy bile duct injury present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and jaundice (in case of strictures).

Investigations show leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes (ALP and GGT). The use of cholangiography helps in delineating the management of bile duct injuries during cholecystectomy.

When a bile duct injury is detected during surgery, the laparoscopic cholecystectomy is changed to an open procedure. If a major injury is discovered and an experienced surgeon is unavailable, an external drain is placed, and the patient is transferred to a referral center.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with progressive difficulty in hearing for the past 3 years. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral cerebellopontine angle tumors that are consistent with schwannomas. There is also a family history of gliomas and meningiomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is neurofibromatosis type 2.

Neurofibromatosis type 2 refers to a syndrome characterized by bilateral schwannomas of the eighth cranial nerve, meningiomas, and gliomas. This is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to a mutation in the NF2 gene.

The image below shows bilateral schwannomas seen in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Other options 

Option A: Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with gliomas of the optic nerve, hamartomas, and pheochromocytomas. These patients have other features like intellectual disability, Lisch nodules (pigmented nodules of the iris), and cafe au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules on the skin).

Option C: Sturge-Weber syndrome presents with port-wine stain lesions of the skin in the area supplied by the trigeminal nerve. They might also have venous angiomas and intellectual disabilities.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis presents with hamartomas and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. Hamartomas appear as cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. This is associated with various cutaneous manifestations like angiofibromas, shagreen patches (localized leathery thickenings), ash-leaf patches (hypopigmented areas), and subungual fibromas.

questions.text: You work in a CHC which has a total number of 50,000 females in the reproductive age group. There were 5000 live births in the past one year in the same town. Unfortunately, in the same time interval, around 10 females also died due to various complications during pregnancy. The district collector has asked for the maternal mortality ratio of the town. The correct response would be
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 200.

The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is calculated using the following formula:

MMR= (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000

MMR = 10/5000 x 100000

MMR = 200

The maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Maternal death is defined as

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • Death during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

In a developing country like India, maternal mortality is a huge public health issue. The most common causes are postpartum hemorrhage and infections, which mainly occur when women do not give birth at hospitals or health centers.

The main contributor to a decline in maternal mortality is the rise in institutional deliveries.

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

Note : Maternal mortality rate is different from maternal mortality ratio. The maternal mortality rate is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 women in reproductive age during the same time period"

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: A young woman was diagnosed with a structural uterine abnormality by hysterosalpingography. Which two anomalies cannot be easily differentiated from each other by this investigation?
questions.solution:
Septate and bicornuate uterus are the two anomalies that cannot be easily differentiated from each other by hysterosalpingography (HSG). HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour. 

A bicornuate uterus is characterized by two separate endometrial cavities, that may communicate with each other and a single uterine cervix. It is caused by the incomplete fusion of the müllerian ducts. Failure of fusion may extend to the cervix, resulting in a complete bicornuate uterus, or may be partial, causing a milder abnormality. 

On HSG, the bicornuate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle >105 degrees. However, MR imaging is necessary to define the external or fundal contour.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity. It is caused by the failure of the medial segments of the müllerian ducts to regress, creating a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project minimally from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. 

On HSG, the intercornual angle is <75 degrees (as shown in the image below). 

Unfortunately, the majority of angles of divergence between the horns fall between 75 and 105 degrees leading to overlapping between the two anomalies on HSG.

Transvaginal 3D ultrasonography (3D TV USG) is the best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus and is recommended for the assessment of patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV US is not possible as in the case of virgins.

Other options:

Uterus Didelphys: A didelphic uterus is characterized by two separate uterine horns, each with an endometrial cavity and cervix. It results from the failure of the fusion of the paired müllerian ducts.

Arcuate uterus: It is characterised by minimal fundal cavity indentation or a slight midline septum within a broad fundus.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who was a nonsmoker came to the medicine department with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Bronchoscopy suggested a lung carcinoma and biopsy showed a lepidic growth pattern. Which of the following is the most likely immunohistochemical marker for this lesion?

choices.text: Thyroid transcription factor-1 and napsin A

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Calretinin and cytokeratin 5/6 positive staining are seen in malignant mesothelioma. It is difficult to differentiate epithelioid mesothelioma grossly and histologically from adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains help to make this differentiation. The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for calretinin immunohistochemical stain.

 

Option C: p40 and p63 are markers of squamous cell carcinoma lung. It is the most common cancer found in smokers. Histologically it is characterized by the presence of keratinization and markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm as shown below.


Option D: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers of small cell carcinoma lung. Due to the encrustation by DNA from the necrotic cancer cells, vascular walls in the necrotic area take up basophilic staining as shown below. This is called the Azzopardi effect.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with a small focal endometrial carcinoma underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 (Co-60 ) isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelerator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotherapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.

questions.text: A patient who came with a complaint of bony swelling in his left  mid thigh was suspected with a bone tumour, likely to be arising from diaphysis of the long bone. Which of the following tumours is the least likely differential for this patient?
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is a benign, chondroid-producing neoplasm composed of chondroblasts that originates in cartilage, which are found in epiphysis; hence they can not origin from diaphysis.

Most chondroblastomas occur in the subchondral epiphyseal region of long bones such as the proximal or distal femur, the proximal tibia and proximal humerus

Typically presents with pain and can cause joint effusion or stiffness. Peak age of incidence is in the teenage years and rare greater than 35 years.

X-ray features: Appear as an oval or round cystic lesion. Appear within epiphysis as a mottled appearance. Histology shows wet sawdust appearance and pathognomonic appearance of chicken wire calcification.

Other options:

Option A: Most common site for ewings sarcoma is diaphysis of femur.

Option B: Most common site for adamantinoma is diaphysis of tibia.

Option C: Most common site for osteoid osteoma is diaphysis of femur.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient complains of fatigue and difficulty in climbing the stairs for the past 2 years. Her symptoms are absent in the morning but worsen as the day progresses. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
Anterior mediastinal mass on CT chest

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of proximal muscle weakness (weakness while climbing the stairs) which worsens as the day progresses, and the image showing bilateral ptosis, are suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). MG shows a decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation. 

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen which triggers this autoimmune reaction. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest (option D).

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay (option A)
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response (option B)
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test (option D): improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of_____________.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture; the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnea
  • Valve stenosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a contraindication for the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) using a kocher’s forceps, and placental abruption is not a contraindication. 
Placental abruption is an indication of induction of labour via surgical methods.

Contraindications for ARM include:

  • Maternal HIV infection with high viral load- rupturing the membranes breaks the physical barrier, introducing the virus into the amniotic fluid and increasing fetal exposure.
  • Maternal GBS infection can spread via a ruptured membrane to the fetus, causing GBS sepsis in the neonate.
  • Unengaged fetal head- when the fetal head is not engaged, the umbilical cord can lie freely below the fetal head, and the sudden decompression can lead to prolapse of the cord, which may compress it, leading to fetal distress. 
  • Chronic hydramnios cause a risk of sudden large-volume drainage of amniotic fluid, leading to sudden decompression and abruption.

  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia

  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios

  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus

  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A woman requests for the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to be performed at 14 weeks of gestation. Which of the following instruments is most likely to be used?
questions.solution:
The device numbered 3 is the ovum forceps, which is used in dilatation and evacuation (D&E) for MTP in the second trimester.

The ovum forceps have got no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. The absence of the catch minimizes uterine injury if accidentally caught. It prevents the crushing of the conceptus. It is to be introduced with the blades closed, to open up inside the uterine cavity, to grasp the products, and to take out the instrument with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movements facilitate the detachment of the products from the uterine wall.

The ovum forceps are also used to

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Remove the laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during hydatid cyst removal.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of the gallbladder during cholecystectomy.
  • Swab an abscess cavity.

Option A: Cord-holding forceps are typically used to hold spermatic cords.

Option B: The image shows a sponge-holding forceps.

It is used to

  • Clean the skin with a swab dipped in an antiseptic solution during all operations.
  • Remove the laminated membrane and daughter cysts during hydatid cyst removal.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy.
  • Swab an abscess cavity.
  • To hold the cervix during cerclage.


Option D: Pile-holding forceps are used to hold hemorrhoids.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?

AFP- Alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller-Duval bodies is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor.

Yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. The tumors are solid masses that are yellow in color and hemorrhagic in nature. Schiller Duval bodies are pathognomonic findings that consist of a central capillary that is surrounded by tumor cells within a cystic area of the tumor. Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated. There is also the presence of intracellular and extracellular hyaline droplets. Clinical features typically include abdominal pain with a rapidly growing abdominal mass. 

Other options:

Option B: Dysgerminoma are the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. These tumor cells grow in sheets or cords and are infiltrated by lymphocytes. These cords are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. 

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin producing cells with an appearance of signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

 

Option D: Granulosa cell tumors arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. The image below shows the presence of Call- Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumor. These are glandlike small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

questions.text: Which structure is located below the canal of the tensor tympani in the anterior wall of the tympanic cavity?
questions.solution:
The canal of tensor tympani is related to the anterior wall of the middle ear and the pharyngotympanic tube is located below it.

The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial & lateral), as shown in the image:

  • Roof: Formed by tegmen tympani bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone called tegmen tympani
  • Anterior wall: Structures related are
    • Canal of tensor tympani
    • Eustachian tube/Pharyngotympanic tube
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall: It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is present above the pyramid.
  • Medial wall:  It is formed by labyrinth and it presents a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to the
    • oval window
    • round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of the facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called scutum.

questions.text:
While doing a preliminary check before surgery, the OT technician noticed a leak in the white-coloured hose. He quickly connects a cylinder with a black body and white shoulders to the anaesthesia apparatus. What will be the PISS for this cylinder?

PISS- Pin Index Safety System
questions.solution:
The white-coloured hose is for oxygen, and the leak warrants using an oxygen cylinder with a black body and white shoulders with a maximum pressure of 2000 psi. The PISS for the cylinder used by the OT technician will be 2, 5.

The medical gases supplied to the anaesthesia workstations are delivered via copper pipelines, which terminate into wall outlets called Schrader sockets. Schrader probes click into these sockets and connect via anti-kink hoses to anaesthetic machines, wall flowmeters, ventilators and other types of equipment. These hoses are colour-coded and labelled. Oxygen is white, nitrous oxide is blue, and air is black. 

When the gases via pipelines are contaminated or defective, or there is a leak, the cylinders containing medical gases are used alternatively.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of chronic back pain and a laterally curved spine is advised conservative management with bracing. Which of the following will be used for the same?
questions.solution:
Boston’s brace (Option A) will be advised for a patient with chronic back pain and a deformed spine, as seen in scoliosis.

Boston brace is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. The below image shows a Boston brace.

Braces are a part of non-operative management of progressive scoliosis of 20- 30 degrees. Compliance is important for the success of the treatment and they need to be worn for more than 20 hours a day (except during sports and bathing).

Other braces for scoliosis include the Milwaukee brace and Reisser’s turn-buckle cast.

Other options:

Option B- Halo ring vest is used for initial traction and reduction of fracture and dislocation of the cervical spine. It consists of four pins inserted into the outer table of the skull and a ring, as shown below.

Option C- Taylor brace is used to support the upper and lower regions of the spinal column while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery. Below is the image of a Taylor's brace.

Option D- SOMI brace (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) is an adjustable brace that provides flexion, neutral or hyperextension positioning and immobilisation of the cervical spine. It offers a level of support between a Philadelphia collar and a halo-type brace. Below is the image of a SOMI brace.

questions.text: A young child with Down's syndrome presents with thickened, fissured skin on the palms and soles, warty crusts on hands and feet, debris under nails, generalised lymphadenopathy, and scrapings revealing mites and eggs. What is the likely treatment for the hyperkeratosis associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human-crusted scabies, and the most likely initial treatment for the hyperkeratosis associated with this condition is topical salicylic acid.

Crusted scabies are characterized by hyperkeratotic skin crust and infestation of up to millions of mites. It occurs in people with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing them to multiply.

It is commonly found in individuals who are immunocompromised, such as those with underlying diseases, HIV infection, or those using topical steroids or pimecrolimus. It is also frequently seen in people with intellectual disabilities, dementia, or Down's syndrome, where a diminished awareness of itching may contribute to delayed diagnosis.

Clinical features include large warty crusts on the hands and feet. Palms and soles are irregularly fissured and thickened. Horny debris gets accumulated beneath the thickened and discoloured nails. Erythema and scaling occur in the scalp face and seborrheic area. The itching will be absent often.

Diagnosis is confirmed by examining the scrappings which reveal mites and eggs.

Management principles include hospitalization and isolation of patients due to the risk of transmission due to physical contact. Oral ivermectin, topical scabicide, and keratolytic agents are used for the crusting.

The images given below show hands in Norwegian scabies.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with sickle-cell anemia was brought by his parents with complaints of fever and a runny nose. The child has a maculopapular rash with a lacy pattern on his trunk and extremities, sparing the palm and soles. He also has a rash on his face as shown below. What specific complication would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms and the typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ that is the erythematous facial flushing as shown in the image are suggestive of erythema infectiosum. A transient aplastic crisis is a complication that is anticipated in this patient. 

Erythema infectiosum or fifth disease is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. It usually has three phases:

  • First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks or slapped cheek appearance. Prodromal symptoms may occur
  • Second phase - begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk
  • Third phase - recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise

Parvovirus B-19-induced transient aplastic crisis is a complication seen in patients with all types of chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Coronary aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease. Patients with this disease present with high fever for at least 5 days along with at least four out of the five characteristic features: polymorphous exanthem, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis with limbal sparing, lip cracking, and oral mucosal erythema with strawberry tongue appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity involvement - erythema of palms and soles with edema of hands and legs.

The image given below shows strawberry tongue and erythema of hands seen in Kawasaki disease.

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of measles. The characteristic presentation of measles includes a high fever, cough, coryza, and a maculopapular rash which typically begins after 3-5 days of fever in a cephalocaudal fashion involving the palms and soles. A pathognomonic feature of measles is the Koplik spots which are bluish-white spots located on the buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd molars.

The image given below shows rashes and Koplik spots of measles.

Option D: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis seen as a complication of group A streptococcal infection (more commonly seen with skin strains and a few pharyngeal strains). Common streptococcal infections in childhood are bacterial pharyngitis, Scarlett fever, non-bullous impetigo, and erysipelas. They present with acute pharyngitis or erythematous papulovesicular lesions which can become purulent.

The image given below shows the rash and strawberry tongue appearance of Scarlett fever.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the emergency department with widespread blistering of the skin and mucous membranes after starting phenytoin for her epilepsy. On examination, there are extensive areas of epidermal detachment covering more than 30% of her BSA. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and the most appropriate initial management for this patient is the immediate discontinuation of phenytoin. This crucial step addresses the underlying cause of her severe skin reaction, preventing further progression of the condition.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome(SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered TEN.

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

SJS/TEN is classified based on the extent of epidermal involvement: 

  • SJS: Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
  • SJS/TEN overlap: Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
  • TEN with spots: Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
  • TEN without spots: Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
     

Septicaemia is a common life-threatening complication. The exposed dermis can act as a substrate for microbial colonization by organisms like S.aureus and P.aeruginosa which can lead to systemic sepsis and multi-organ failure. Other complications include hypothermia, anaemia, fluid loss, and hypoalbuminemia. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of the skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.

questions.text: A female patient with CKD was catheterised to monitor urine output, following which she developed suprapubic pain with fever and chills. A catheter-associated urinary tract infection diagnosis was made, and urine was sent for culture. The following growth was seen on MacConkey agar, and the organism exhibited a motility similar to Bacillus cereus. Identify the organism and its biochemical characteristics.
questions.solution:
The female patient with catheter-associated UTI with non-lactose fermenting, pale colonies on MacConkey agar, as shown in the image, with a motility pattern similar to bacillus cereus, is proteus, and it is methyl red positive.

Proteus mirabilis is a gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile bacilli, which is an opportunistic urinary and nosocomial pathogen and often causes urinary tract infections in hospitalised patients following instrumentation. Proteus exhibits swarming on solid culture media wherein the colonies spread in a wave pattern, forming concentric circles

Proteus produces urease, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide, producing a characteristic putrid or fishy odour in culture. 
On MacConkey agar, it produces non-lactose fermenting pale colonies, as shown below.  
Lactose fermenters (CEEK)- Citrobacter, Escherichia, Enterobacter, Klebsiella (Shigella sonnei is a late lactose fermenter.

The characteristic feature of proteus is the presence of the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase, converting phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA reaction). Protease also shows positivity for methyl red, but the Voges- Proskauer reaction is negative.

Other options:

Option A- E. coli is a common cause of UTI, but it ferments lactose, producing pink colonies on MacConkey and is motile by peritrichous flagella but does not show swarming. E. coli shows positivity for indole and methyl red.

Option B- Klebsiella is a lactose fermenting and is non-motile. It utilises citrate, produces urease and is Voges- Proskauer reaction positive.

IMViC- Indole, Methyl red, Voges- Proskauer, Citrate:  E.coli IMViC (+ + - -)  , Klebsiella IMViC (- - + +)

Option D- Enterococcus is a gram-positive cocci, non-hemolytic, tolerates heat (60°c), non-motile, ferments lactose and is bile-esculin positive.

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is Glycine.

Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of negative feedback inhibition. The axon of a spinal motor neuron gives a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. This inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

The Renshaw cell releases glycine to reduce the activity of the motor neuron.

questions.text: A female patient had contractions and started expelling the placenta following the delivery of the baby. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the peripheral placental separation shown in the image below?

choices.text: It is commonly known as Schultz method
It takes place during second stage of labour
The maternal surface of placenta appears first at vulva
This is an abnormal method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates that the patient is in the third stage of labor and the above image shows the Mathews-Duncan method of placental separation which begins at the periphery. Here, the maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

The third stage of labor starts after fetal delivery and involves the detachment and expulsion of the placenta and membranes. There are two normal mechanisms by which placental separation occurs:

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the periphery of the placenta. The blood collects between the membranes and uterine wall and escapes out from the vagina. 
  • Here, as the placenta separation is sideways, the maternal surface appears first.

Schultze method:

  • The method of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at the vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clots.

The below image shows:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as the Schultze method
B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. An X-ray was taken, which is shown below. Following a closed reduction, the patient developed a foot drop. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
A foot drop following a closed reduction of the posterior hip dislocation (indicated by the given X-ray) suggests a new onset sciatic nerve injury and surgical exploration is the next best step to rule out nerve entrapment that may have occurred during reduction. 

The clinical history of an RTA and the X-ray findings show a broken Shenton’s line, upward displacement of the femur head, and non-visualisation of lesser trochanter as shown below, indicating shortening of the limb, adduction, flexion and internal rotation of the limb seen in posterior hip dislocation.

The management of posterior hip dislocation without associated femur or acetabular fractures is an immediate closed reduction to prevent osteochondritis and osteoarthritis. Sciatic nerve function should be tested before reduction as injury can occur during reduction, which may lead to a foot drop and decreased sensations below the knee, except for the medial aspect (sural nerve). A toe-raising splint (Option A) is the treatment for foot drop to aid mobility and prevent deformity, but the immediate next step will be to explore for injury and repair. 

Other options: 

Option C- The below-knee cast is a circumferential cast used for immobilising fractures and ligamentous injuries of the lower limb.

Option D- A stirrup splint is used for support in ankle sprains and foot injuries

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with superior mesenteric artery occlusion underwent extensive bowel resection. Following surgery, he developed intractable diarrhoea and steatorrhea. Which of the following is not correct concerning your diagnosis?

choices.text: Home parenteral nutrition is the mainstay of treatment
Teduglutide, a GLP-1 agonist, is approved for this condition
Intestinal transplantation is indicated in complicated cases

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient with superior mesenteric artery occlusion and extensive bowel resection now presenting with intractable diarrhoea and steatorrhea suggests short bowel syndrome. Teduglutide is a GLP-2 agonist (not GLP-1 agonist) approved for this condition.

Short bowel syndrome refers to intractable diarrhea with malabsorption of nutrients after intestinal resection or intestinal bypass surgery leading to malnutrition. The features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when the length is less than 200 cm of the small bowel, but the length and nature of the remaining bowel are also important.

The common causes of short bowel syndrome include acute mesenteric ischemia, Crohn’s disease, trauma and radiation enteritis in adults, and bowel atresia and midgut volvulus in children

The clinical features include:

  • Intractable Diarrhea (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion, or unabsorbed bile salts in the colon)
  • Steatorrhea (due to the depletion of the bile salt pool)
  • Gallstones (due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts)
  • Renal stones (due to increased absorption of oxalate in the colon)
  • Peptic ulcer (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion)
  • Fat-soluble (vitamin A, D, E, and K) and B12 vitamin deficiencies

Initial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhea by initiating total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Home parenteral nutrition is the mainstay of the treatment. Long-term management involves:

  • Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts
  • Dietary fat restriction
  • Parenteral vitamin and mineral supplements
  • Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH
  • Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions
  • Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transit
  • Hormonal therapy such as growth hormone, glutamine, and GLP-2 (glucagon-like peptide-2) analog (teduglutide) are used to promote intestinal adaptation.     

Small intestine lengthening procedures done to increase absorption and transit time are:

  • Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring procedure (LILT) (Bianchi procedure)
  • Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP)

Intestinal transplantation is indicated in complicated cases.

questions.text: After a building collapse, multiple patients were rescued and brought to your casualty. Which among the following injuries will you triage under the yellow category?
questions.solution:
Compound fractures are classified under the yellow category.

The yellow (medium priority) category includes patients who need resuscitation or surgery within 24 hours and have a good chance of survival with prompt treatment. Spinal injuries, along with moderate head injuries, compound fractures, and pelvic fractures, typically fall under this category due to the potential for delayed complications.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention into four categories- red (high priority), yellow (medium priority), green (low priority) and black (least priority). It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. It lessens the burden on medical facilities.

Other options:

Option A- A small forearm laceration will be classified under the green category

Options B and D- Flail chest and severe facial trauma will come under the red category.
