questions.text: A middle-aged woman came with complaints of pain in her hand. Performing the following test for 30 seconds led to the development of paresthesia over the thumb, index finger, and middle finger. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test being performed above is Durkan’s test or carpal tunnel compression test. It is suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a type of compression neuropathy that results from median nerve compression within the carpal tunnel. The symptoms include tingling and numbness in the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, long, and radial side of ring fingers). Pain is deep, aching, or throbbing, occurs diffusely in the hand and may radiate up the forearm. It occurs most often in patients 30 to 60 years old and is two to three times more common in women than in men. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, the sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve (Tinel’s sign) or by holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds (Phalen’s test). The carpal compression test (Durkan’s test) involves applying direct compression to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs producing paresthesia over the median nerve distribution. It is more specific and more sensitive than either the Tinel or Phalen test.

In late cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction and sensory deficit in the median nerve territory. Electrodiagnostic tests, which show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist and increased latency are reliable confirmatory tests. Management involves night splints and steroid infiltration in the early stages. Definitive management is by surgical decompression/release of the carpal tunnel by division of the transverse carpal ligament.

Other options: 

Option A and B: Pronator syndrome and AIN syndromes are proximal median nerve compression syndromes and Durkan’s test is not positive in these cases. Tinel’s sign may be positive over the nerve proximally but not at the carpal tunnel.

Option C: PIN syndrome is a pure motor disorder and there are no sensory symptoms. There is a weakness in the metacarpophalangeal joint extension.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about anemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients?

choices.text: Epoetin and Darbepoetin are a mainstay of treatment
Iron replacement with ferric carboxymaltose usually requires more than 3 doses
Oral iron therapy should be tried first in patients not on dialysis

questions.solution:
The statement "Iron replacement with ferric carboxymaltose usually requires more than 3 doses" is not true as it can be replaced in 1-2 infusions.

Newer IV iron compounds like ferumoxytol and ferric carboxymaltose feature stable carbohydrate shells that prevent the release of toxic-free iron, allowing for larger replacement doses and minimizing oxidative stress during treatment. Iron requirement can be fulfilled in just 1-2 infusions.

Human recombinant erythropoietin eg: darbepoetin is the best treatment for anemia in CKD (chronic kidney disease) patients.

The anemia of CKD is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Hence, erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs, eg, epoetin and darbepoetin) become the mainstay of treatment in anemia of CKD.

However, iron stores must be adequate to ensure a response to ESAs. Since iron deficiency is common in CKD patients, iron therapy is a crucial initial step in their management.

Treatment options for the management of anemia in CKD:

  • Recombinant human ESA
  • Iron supplementation: Oral preferred, IV given only if GI intolerance to oral therapy.
  • Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation
  • Blood transfusion: Indicated only in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy.

Note: Daprudostat is an oral prolyl hydroxylase inhibitor of hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) approved for treatment of anemia in CKD patient on dialysis for longer than 4 months.

questions.text: During your casualty postings, a body of a person who committed suicide by hanging was brought to casualty by the police officer.  You notice the mark of ligature knot on the right lateral side of the neck along with the closure of the left eye. Which of the following is most likely finding you would notice in the right eye?
questions.solution:
The right eye remains open with the dilated pupil as the right ligature knot would compresses the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck.

Eyes may show the following findings,

  • Le facies sympathique: In case of hanging, one of the eyes may be opened with dilated pupil, while the other eye may be closed. This occurs due to the pressure of the ligature knot on the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck. Thus, the side on which the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic ganglia, the eye remains open with dilatation of its pupil.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • Prominent eyeballs

Other findings:

  • Post-mortem hypostasis - present in the legs and hands.
  • Petechial hemorrhages - these are usually the exception, rather than the rule.
  • Congestion of the face - less commonly seen than a pale face
  • Ligature mark - above the thyroid cartilage and incomplete
  • Soft tissue hemorrhage may be seen.
  • Laryngeal fractures - fractures of hyoid and thyroid may be seen.
  • Amussat sign - damage to intima and media of the carotid artery
  • Simon's sign - hemorrhages on the anterior aspects of intervertebral discs.
  • Dribbling of saliva - Many textbooks of forensic medicine states that the dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of hanging having taken place during life, as the secretion of saliva is a vital function can't occur after death. But, salivation may not occur when the death is due to vagal inhibition or injury to the spinal cord.

questions.text: The sequence of the non-template strand in a DNA fragment is TAAAGC. The mRNA that will be transcribed from the anti-sense strand will have the following sequence______
questions.solution:
UAAAGC will be the sequence of mRNA produced from this fragment of DNA (the non-template strand, which is TAAAGC), while the template strand will have a complementary sequence of ATTTCG.

The non-template strand or, coding strand, or sense/plus strand in the DNA, will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of UAAAGC would correspond to a DNA sequence on the non-template strand of TAAAGC.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be ATTTCG (written 5′ to 3′).

Note:

Template strand - known as minus or, antisense or non-coding strand.

Coding strand- known as plus or, sense or non-template strand.

questions.text: Which of the following epilepsy disorders is incorrectly paired with the major mechanism of its first-line drug of management?

choices.text: Twitching and tingling of thumb progressing to entire limb- sodium channel blocker
Child with history of poor concentration and daydreaming- synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2A inhibitor
Adolescent with early morning clumsiness of hand – sodium and calcium channel blocker
Child with tuberous sclerosis and spasms of neck and hands- GABA transaminase inhibitor

questions.solution:
The child with a history of poor concentration and daydreaming is most likely suffering from absence seizures, and the synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2A (SV2A) inhibitor (levetiracetam) is not the first-line drug for this condition. The first-line drugs for absence seizures are:

  • ethosuximide- calcium channel inhibitor
  • sodium valproate- inhibits sodium channel, calcium channel, and GABA transaminase.

In absence seizures, the child has a sudden onset of impaired awareness and unresponsiveness with characteristic staring and discontinuation of any ongoing activities, which lasts less than 30 seconds and stops abruptly. The posture of the child is maintained, and there is no obvious movement, which often makes it difficult to diagnose and presents as a child having difficulties in concentrating and daydreaming. There can be associated memory loss and automatisms (repeated movements).

Option A- Twitching and tingling sensation in the thumb progressing to the entire limb in a spreading manner is characteristic of focal onset seizures with characteristic Jacksonian march. The first-line drug for focal/partial seizures is carbamazepine, which is a sodium channel blocker.

Option C- The adolescent with early morning clumsiness of the hand is likely a case of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The first line drug for JME is sodium valproate.

Option D- The child with tuberous sclerosis and spasms of neck and hands has infantile spasms with hypsarrythmia associated with tuberous sclerosis, and the first-line drug is vigabatrin, which is a GABA transaminase inhibitor.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered via cesarean section due to fetal distress. Shortly after birth, the infant exhibits bilious vomiting and fails to pass meconium. On physical examination, the abdomen appears distended, and hypoactive bowel sounds are noted. X-ray abdomen reveals a double bubble sign. Identify the radiological finding shown in the image, obtained on barium study.
questions.solution:
A newborn presents with bilious vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and abdominal distension, leading to a diagnosis of duodenal atresia indicated by the double bubble sign on the X-ray. The radiological finding obtained on the barium study is a windsock deformity.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Non-bilious vomiting would favour a more proximal obstruction, such as in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

The plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign:

Three types of duodenal atresia are described as follows:

Type I: most common; mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity)
Type II: two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present
Type III: complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum

Intestinal obstruction from atresias, more common in the jejunum, presents with hypoactive bowel sounds, abdominal distension, and bilious emesis. Proximal atresia shows less distension but significant emesis, with air-fluid levels and absent distal gas on radiographs. Distal atresia causes more distension. Initial management includes nasogastric decompression, IV fluids, and parenteral nutrition. Evaluation for associated anomalies includes echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and chest/spine radiographs. The surgical treatment is Kimura's duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: The string sign on the barium enema is in ileocecal tuberculosis.

Option B: Rigler sign is also called a double-wall sign which is seen on an abdominal radiograph when gas is lining both sides of the bowel wall, observed in pneumoperitoneum, as shown below.

Option D: Apple peel deformity, also known as Christmas tree Deformity is seen in type IIIb jejunoileal atresia where there is a large mesenteric gap between atretic segments and the distal loop gets retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A young patient presents with painless central loss of vision. The fundus examination is shown below. Which among the following is not correct about this condition?

choices.text: It is due to mutation in VMD2 gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient presenting with painless central loss of vision (macular pathology) with image showing egg-yolk appearance in the macular region suggests Best’s disease and the incorrect statement is Normal EOG with Abnormal ERG.

Best's disease/Vitelliform macular dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula causing progressive central vision loss. It is autosomal-dominant and linked to the mutation in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene. It is primarily a cone dystrophy, though in later stages rods also may get involved.

It is characterized by bilateral yellow, yolk-like (vitelliform) macular lesions.

The stages of evolution of the macular lesions are described as progressing from:

  • Pre-vitelliform stage
  • Vitelliform stage- scrambled egg stage with or without hypopyon
  • Vitelliruptive- the lesion breaks and visual acuity drops
  • The atrophic stage

Patients with Best’s disease usually have good visual acuity when the "yolk" remains intact.

Diagnosis: This is the only disease with relatively normal ERG results associated with an abnormal EOG. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) reveals that the vitelliform material appears as a dome-shaped, hyperreflective, and homogenous lesion, located below the hyperreflective photoreceptor layer.

Arden ratio is less than 1.5 when normal it is around 1.85.

Fundus autofluorescence shows intense hyper- autofluorescence of the yellowish lesions and hypoautofluorescence of the atrophic area.

questions.text: A senior resident on rounds teaches the interns about the following case given in the image. He asks them about the plan of management of this patient. Which among the following will be unlikely to be on his charts?
questions.solution:
The given condition in the image is necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal region i.e. Fournier gangrene. Delayed surgical excision is unlikely to be done.

Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, and diabetes. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the Dartos, Scarpa, and Colles fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. 

Clinical features of Fournier gangrene are scrotal pain, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected.

Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The steps in the management of this condition:

  • IV fluids 
  • IV antibiotics (Option A)
  • Urgent surgical excision followed by skin grafting in later stages. Wide surgical excision is often necessary. (Option D)
  • Urinary and fecal diversion may be necessary. (Option C)

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. (Option B). Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode. Despite the best therapy, mortality rates are around 50%.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of hearing loss in her right ear for the past few months. She denies any pain or discharge. An impedance audiometry graph is provided below. Which of the following conditions is most likely present?
questions.solution:
The impedance audiometry graph provided shows an "Ad" curve, which is observed in cases of ossicular discontinuity.

Impedance audiometry is an objective test that includes tympanometry and assessment of acoustic reflexes. The principle behind this test is that when sound strikes the tympanic membrane, a portion is absorbed while the rest is reflected. The reflected sound is measured to evaluate the compliance of the tympanic membrane. In the case of ossicular discontinuity, the compliance of the tympanostapedial system is significantly increased, leading to the "Ad" configuration observed on the graph.

The "Ad" curve indicates that there is increased compliance of the tympanic membrane, which typically occurs in conditions where the ossicular chain is not functioning properly or also in cases of thin, lax tympanic membrane. This condition arises when there is a separation or disruption of the ossicles, often due to trauma or chronic middle ear disease. As a result, the mechanical connection between the tympanic membrane and the inner ear is compromised, leading to abnormal transmission of sound vibrations and resulting in conductive hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl presents with nasal obstruction, headaches, and sleep disturbances due to snoring. Examination reveals a deviated nasal septum with a prominent C-shaped deformity on the left side. A decision is made to proceed with a corrective procedure using an incision as shown below. What is the type of incision used?
questions.solution:
The type of incision used here as shown in the image is Freer's incision.

Septoplasty is a conservative technique in the surgical correction of septal deformity. The key advantage is that it can be carried out as a daycare procedure, most of the bone and cartilage are retained, and complications are less. The deformed septum may corrected by various techniques like scoring the concave side, shaving, and wedge excision. Sometimes realignment by joining straight pieces of the septum outside the nose and replacing them can be done, called extracorporeal septoplasty.

Indications include:

  • Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches
  • Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media
  • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur
  • Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndrome
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty in cosmetic surgery
Septoplasty Submucous resection
Conservative procedure Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage
Done in children and adults Not done in < 18 yrs
Freer’s hemitransfixion incision is used Killian’s incision(Option B) is used
Flaps raised on only one side Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum
Fewer complications More complications
Reoperation is easier Reoperation is difficult

 

Other options:

Option A: The incision in the image below is the Lynch incision (external ethmoid incision), which exposes the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries.

Option D: The image shows Weber Ferugson's incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma to perform median maxillectomy. A median maxillectomy involves surgical resection of the medial and superomedial walls of the maxillary antrum done for maxillary carcinoma.

questions.text: An accused of the rape incident and the victim is brought to the forensic department, which of the following statement is correct regarding the examination of the accused and rape victim.

choices.text: Medical examination of the victim of rape is done under BNSS 194
The accused can be examined without his consent under  BNSS 52
Absence of smegma rules out the possibility of complete penetration
The victim’s DNA can be recovered from a penile swab up to 48 hours after intercourse

questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the examination of the accused and rape victim is option B i.e., The accused can be examined without his consent at the request of a police officer under BNSS 52.

BNSS: Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita

CrPC: Code of Criminal Procedure

BNSS 52/CrPC 53A deals with the examination of the accused of rape by a medical practitioner.

BNSS 184/CrPC164A deals with the medical examination of the victim of rape. (option A)

BNSS 194/CrPC174 deals with police to enquire and report on suicide, etc.(police inquest)

Other options :

Option C: The presence of smegma rules out the possibility of complete penetration because smegma gets rubbed off during intercourse. The absence of smegma may indicate that intercourse might have been performed. Smegma will also be removed by bathing or washing. it usually takes 24 hours for smegma to collect.

Option D: The victim’s DNA can be recovered from a penile swab up to 24 hours after intercourse if the individual has not taken a bath.

Specimens to be collected from the accused are swabs from the coronal sulcus, prepuce, penile shaft, urethral orifice, blood for grouping, pubic hair, head hair, and nail scrapings.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication for the procedure in which the following instrument is used?
questions.solution:
The instrument in the image is Rubin’s cannula, used for hysterosalpingography, and pelvic endometriosis is a complication of this procedure which can occur if it is done during or before menstruation.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an outpatient radiological procedure where a radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity. The dye is visualised by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It is performed between days 5 and 10 of the menstrual cycle as during this time, the cessation of menstrual flow reduces the risk of infections and flushing of the ovum from the fallopian tube following ovulation.

Indications: 

  • Patency of fallopian tubes and evaluation of tubal blocks
  • Uterine anomalies like septate and bicornuate uterus
  • Uterine synechiae- Asherman syndrome (Option B)
  • Uterine polyps (Option D)
  • Cervical incompetency and narrowing (Option D)
  • Feasibility of tuboplasty by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Contraindications:

  • Acute genital tract infection
  • Active uterine bleeding
  • Premenstrual phase- pregnancy may have occurred
  • Genital tuberculosis due to the risk of spreading infection
  • Iodine allergy

Complications:

  • Ascending infections- tubercular and other pelvic infections
  • Chemical peritonitis- pelvic irritation and pain
  • Pelvic endometriosis
  • Allergic reaction to the dye

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A primigravida at 37 weeks with decreased fetal movements had the following findings on the 30-minute biophysical profile. What will be the most appropriate next step?
  • NST- reactive
  • 2 episodes of breathing movements
  • 2 amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2x2 cm each
  • No body movements and muscle tone
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step would be immediate delivery and termination of the pregnancy. 

A reactive NST, 2 episodes of breathing movements, 2 amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2x2 cm each and no body movements (2+2+2+0+0 = 6). A manning score of 6 at ≥ 37 weeks is managed by termination of pregnancy.

Biophysical profile is a multi-parametric screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components and the observations are made for 30 minutes.

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria
Non-stress Test (NST)   ≥2 accelerations within 20-40 minutes.
Fetal breathing movements   ≥ 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting > 30 seconds.
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone   ≥ 1 episode of active extension(limb or trunk) with return of flexion.
Amniotic fluid volume A pocket of amniotic fluid that measures at least 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket)

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So, the total maximum score will be 10. A score of 4 or less indicates fetal acidemia.

Interpretation and management of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly 
8 with normal AFV Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly
8 with decreased AFV Suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia

If ≥36 weeks, delivery is done
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

If AFV is abnormal-Deliver>36 weeks.

If AFV is normal- deliver≥ 37 weeks. 
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

If ≥32 weeks, deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Delivery 

The modified biophysical score has only 2 components, i.e. NST and amniotic fluid index (AFI). It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He is complaining of breathlessness for the past 3 days. A chest radiograph was taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia as the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in streptococcal pneumonia

questions.text: A researcher plots the following graph while analyzing the UV  absorbance spectrum of amino acids. Which amino acid does the blue curve indicate?
questions.solution:
Here the blue curve represents tryptophan, which shows maximum UV absorbance at 280 nm wavelength.

Amino Acids absorb UV light due to aromatic ring. Aromatic amino acids such as tyrosine, tryptophan, and phenylalanine absorb 250 to 290 nm UV light. The maximum absorption of UV light is by tryptophan. Because tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine. It shows maximum absorption at 280 nm.

Absorption of UV light by amino acids:

  • Amino acids do not absorb visible light and thus are colourless.
  • Compounds with conjugated double bonds absorb UV light. That is why aromatic amino acids, porphyrins, purine, and pyrimidine bases absorb UV light. Among the aromatic amino acids, tyrosine, phenylalanine, and especially tryptophan absorb high-wavelength (250-290 nm) ultraviolet light.
  • Light absorbing capacity of aromatic amino acids is used to estimate the protein concentration with a spectrophotometer (an instrument that can measure the light absorbance from infrared to ultraviolet range).
  • With the absorbance value of a known concentration of protein solutions, a standard curve is made. The concentration of the protein is calculated using the standard curve.

The light absorption wavelength range of compounds:

Compound λ max (nm)(wavelength at which maximal light absorption occurs)
Peptide bond 190 - 230
Purine and pyrimidine bases 260
Aromatic amino acids 280
NADH & NADPH 340
Porphyrin 400

questions.text: A pregnant woman in labor presented with excessive vaginal bleeding. The non-stress test showed sinusoidal fetal heart rate tracing. An ultrasound during her second trimester showed a cord that lacked Wharton's jelly. Which of the following placentas could lead to this pregnancy outcome?
questions.solution:
Placenta shown in image 3 is a velamentous placenta which can lead to excessive vaginal bleeding during labor and sinusoidal pattern NST.

In a velamentous placenta, the umbilical cord does not insert into the center of the placenta, but the vessels traverse between the placental membranes (amnion and chorion), unprotected by Wharton's jelly, before reaching the placenta. If these vessels lie over the internal os, near the presenting part, it is called vasa previa and may present as vaginal bleeding, which is predominantly fetal blood causing fetal distress.  

Below is an image of the velamentous placenta. 

The sinusoidal pattern of fetal heart rate (FHR) has a fixed or absent baseline variability and absent accelerations for ≥ 30 minutes. This pattern is suggestive of fetal anemia, vasa previa, fetal hypoxia, and acidosis.

Below is a cardiotocograph showing a sinusoidal pattern resembling a sine wave. 

Other options:

Option A- Image 1 is of the battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. It can lead to cord compression and variable deceleration, leading to fetal anoxia and death.

Option B- Image 2 is of the circumvallate placenta where the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and the fetal surface is surrounded by a thickened fold of amnion, chorion, fibrin and decidua vera. It can cause antepartum hemorrhage, fetal growth retardation, and preterm delivery.

Option D- Image 4 is of placenta succenturiata with one or more small lobes of placenta connected by a leash of vessels. This can lead to the retained placenta, postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution, uterine sepsis, and polyp formation. Although succenturiate placenta can also cause vasa previa, the USG finding of lack of placental tissue points toward velamentous cord insertion and is, hence, the answer.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child was brought to the emergency with 2nd-degree deep burns of 20% TBSA. The weight of the child is 45 kg. How much fluid should be given to the child in the first 8 hours?

TBSA: Total body surface area
questions.solution:
The total fluid requirement in a 12-year-old child, weighing 45 kg with 2nd-degree deep burns over 20% TBSA would be 2700 ml. Out of this, 1350 ml would be given in the first 8 hours and the remaining in the next 16 hours.

Calculation:

According to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines, for children under 14 years having 2nd and 3rd-degree burns, the Parkland formula for fluid resuscitation is :

Total fluid requirement : 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA

Therefore, 3 x 45 x 20 = 2700 ml.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours i.e 1350 ml, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: Which of the following skull fracture is called the signature fracture?
questions.solution:
Depressed fracture is called the signature fracture.

It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. The fracture shape indicates the type of weapon which produced it. So it is also called signature fracture/ fracture ala signature/ Bone impression fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed an injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane. The extravasated urine is likely to get accumulated in ________.
questions.solution:
Injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane leads to the accumulation of urine in the superficial perineal pouch.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata. 

 

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of perineal artery (Posterior scrotal and Transverse perineal arteries) and Branches of artery of penis (Artery to bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of penis and dorsal artery of penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, Branches of perineal nerve (Posterior scrotal, Nerve to bulb and Muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

 

Other options - 

Option A: Deep perineal pouch encloses the space between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Thus, any injury to urethra in this pouch can lead to the accumulation of urine in the deep perineal pouch. It can even spread upwards into the extraperitoneal space around the bladder and prostate and into the anterior abdominal wall. 

Option C: Space of Retzius, also known as the retropubic space is an extraperitoneal space located posterior to the pubic symphysis and anterior to the urinary bladder. 

Option D: Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch in females, or rectovesical pouch in males, is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the erect position. Any infection or fluid collection tends to get accumulated in this dependent region.

questions.text:
A patient presents with the findings given below. Which among the following histories are you likely to see in this patient's case notes?

Low pO2
Normal pCO2
High Alveolar-arterial gradient (pAO2-paO2)

choices.text: Sedative drug overdose with shallow breathing and drowsiness
Sudden onset of chest pain, shortness of breath, and positive D-dimer
Progressive muscle weakness, ptosis, and fatigue
Recent viral infection followed by ascending paralysis and weakness

questions.solution:
The given findings—low pO2, normal pCO2, and high Alveolar-arterial gradient  (pAO2-paO2) suggests Type 1 respiratory failure (hypoxemic respiratory failure). The most expected history would be sudden onset of chest pain, shortness of breath, and positive D-dimer which is consistent with pulmonary embolism.

Type 1 respiratory failure, commonly seen in conditions causing a ventilation-perfusion mismatch or impaired oxygen diffusion. Pulmonary embolism (PE)  leads to ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, where parts of the lung are ventilated but not perfused, resulting in low arterial oxygen levels (hypoxemia). In PE, the obstruction of pulmonary blood flow prevents effective gas exchange, causing a significant increase in the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (A-a gradient) while maintaining normal or low carbon dioxide levels (pCO2). This impaired oxygenation, with normal ventilation, characterizes Type 1 respiratory failure.

Other causes of Type 1 respiratory failure include pneumonia, sepsis, gastric aspiration, pancreatitis, multiple blood transfusions and near drowning.

Other options:

Option A: Sedative drug overdose with shallow breathing and drowsiness would lead to Type 2 respiratory failure (hypoventilation) and an increase in pCO2.

Option C : Progressive muscle weakness, ptosis, and fatigue suggestive of myasthenia gravis predominantly causes Type 2 respiratory failure due to respiratory muscle weakness, leading to hypercapnia.

Option D : Recent viral infection followed by ascending paralysis and weakness suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome also predominantly causes Type 2 respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, the retina appeared convex and detached with no evidence of breaks. Which among the following signs is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The case is suggestive of serous or exudative retinal detachment, and the presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature.

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. The causes include:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis. Clinical signs include:

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • Detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign- Subretinal fluid detaches the area of the retina under which it accumulates. In the upright position, it collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens, the fluid shifts posteriorly which detaches the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots- Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Other options:

Options B and C: Relative afferent pupillary defect and Schaffer sign are seen in rhegmatogenous RD. Schaffer's sign refers to tobacco dust appearance in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. 

Option D- Reduced retinal mobility is seen in tractional retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl child was brought to the clinic with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. On examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. The chest radiograph of the infant is shown below. Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a chest x-ray image showing cardiomegaly is suggestive of Pompe disease. This disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme acid maltase.

Pompe disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells.

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, cardiomegaly, and macroglossia.

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen, as shown below.

Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant acid α-glucosidase (alglucosidase alfa).

Other options

Option A- Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease. Patients present commonly at 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- Myophosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle disease leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain, and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Muscle phosphofructokinase deficiency causes Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder). The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A patient presenting with altered sensorium and reduced plasma copeptin levels is diagnosed with central diabetes insipidus. Which one of the following is correct regarding this patient?

choices.text: High serum sodium, low urine osmolality
Low serum sodium, high urine osmolality
High serum sodium, normal urine osmolality
Normal serum sodium, low urine osmolality

questions.solution:
The patient with altered sensorium and reduced plasma copeptin levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus (DI), will have high serum sodium and low urine osmolality.
 
In post-traumatic DI, patients lose their ability to concentrate urine due to the failure of anti-diuretic hormone secretion in acceleration-deceleration injury, leading to ischemia and discontinuity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This leads to hypotonic polyuria with low osmolality.

When this is associated with altered mentation and damage to the central osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus, thirst regulation is also impaired, preventing adequate fluid intake to compensate for the losses, leading to severe hypernatremia.

Plasma copeptin level is a surrogate marker of vasopressin, as both are derived from the same precursor. Reduced levels of copeptin indicate reduced vasopressin production.

questions.text: The autopsy of a 1-year-old child who died of congestive cardiac failure revealed multiple tumours of the heart located in the ventricles. The histopathologic findings is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells which are characteristic of cardiac rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, cardiac rhabdomyomas are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Histologic processing of the sample usually removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands. These strands stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This gives an appearance that resembles a spider and is hence referred to as spider cells.

Rhabdomyomas are mostly seen in the first year of life. They are discovered when there is an obstruction to a valvular orifice or cardiac chamber. Approximately half the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations. The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are usually multiple and appear in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas and not true neoplasms.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the adult heart. Unlike rhabdomyomas, they are usually single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Papillary fibroelastomas are mainly present in the valves. It appears as a cluster of hairlike projections up to 1 cm in length.

questions.text: A drug addict presented to the casualty in a confused, agitated state. He is sweating profusely. On examination, he has tachycardia, tachypnea and increased core body temperature. Which of the following drugs will cause a similar ocular finding as seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a drug addict with profuse sweating, tachycardia, tachypnea, increased body temperature and agitation points to a sympathomimetic toxidrome like cocaine overdose. The ocular finding in cocaine overdose would be mydriasis, and Phenylephrine, being an alpha agonist, causes active mydriasis. 

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the α1 receptors present on the radial dilator pupillae causing their contraction and hence mydriasis. 
Pilocarpine, physostigmine and phenoxybenzamine cause miosis. Pilocarpine and physostigmine are parasympathomimetics that cause active miosis by M3 stimulation in constrictor pupillae. Phenoxybenzamine is a sympatholytic that causes passive miosis by α1 blockade in dilator pupillae.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with 3 months of progressive fatigue, recurrent infections, and easy bruising. On exam, she is pale with petechiae but no hepatosplenomegaly. CBC shows Hb 7.5 g/dL, WBC 2,300/µL, platelets 30,000/µL, low reticulocyte count, and a peripheral smear shows no circulating blasts. Bone marrow biopsy shows hypercellularity with blasts >20%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of the patient with pancytopenia, low reticulocyte count, no blasts in peripheral blood with hypercellular bone marrow with blasts >20% is suggestive of a diagnosis of Aleukemic leukemia.

Aleukemic leukemia is a form of leukemia characterized by the presence of leukemic cells in the bone marrow while the peripheral blood shows few or no circulating blasts. This condition often presents with the clinical features of anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, recurrent infections, and easy bruising. 

The pathophysiology of aleukemic leukemia involves the infiltration of malignant cells into the bone marrow, disrupting normal hematopoiesis. As a result, patients experience significant pancytopenia due to the overcrowding of the marrow by leukemic blasts. The hypercellular bone marrow often contains a high percentage of immature blasts, but these cells may not spill over into the bloodstream. The absence of circulating blasts is a key distinguishing feature that separates aleukemic leukemia from more typical forms of acute leukemia.

Diagnosis typically involves a bone marrow biopsy, which reveals hypercellularity with significant blast infiltration. While peripheral blood studies may show normal or low white blood cell counts. Treatment strategies may involve chemotherapy or targeted therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Aplastic Anemia would show pancytopenia with a hypocellular bone marrow, not hypercellularity with blasts.

Option B: Pure Red Cell Aplasia would primarily affect red blood cell production and not explain the leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

Option D: Myelodysplastic Syndrome could present with pancytopenia with a hypercellular marrow but has blasts less than 20% with absent peripheral circulation

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with superior oblique muscle palsy. Identify the site of the lesion in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The superior oblique muscle, innervated by the trochlear nerve from the midbrain's dorsal side at the level of the inferior colliculus (marked as 2), is likely the site of the lesion.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve.
  • Only cranial nerve with dorsal exit. All other cranial nerves exit the brainstem from the ventral surface.
  • Emerges from the dorsal midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course.
  • Only nerve with internal decussation.

The following image shows Trochlear nuclei situated in the dorsal aspect of the midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus.

The following image shows the Oculomotor nuclei at the level of superior colliculus of midbrain.

Level Inferior colliculus Superior colliculus
Cavity Cerebral Aqueduct Cerebral aqueduct
Nuclei Inferior colliculus, substantia nigra, trochlear nucleus, mesencephalic nucleus of V nerve Superior colliculus, substantia nigra, trochlear nucleus, mesencephalic nucleus of V nerve, oculomotor nucleus, Edinger- Westphal nucleus, red nucleus
Motor tract Corticospinal and corticonuclear tracts, temporopontine, frontopontine, medial longitudinal fasciculus Corticospinal and corticonuclear tracts, temporopontine, frontopontine, medial longitudinal fasciculus, decussation of rubrospinal tract

Superior oblique muscle palsy causes hypertropia, limited downward movement, and difficulty moving the eye towards the sound side. The head tilts downward and towards the unaffected side, and homonymous diplopia occurs when looking down, with the false image lower and tilted. Patients often have trouble descending stairs and experience prominent vertigo.

  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus

questions.text:
The cross-section of an embryo at the end of the fourth week is shown below. The derivates of the structure labeled as '?' are:

1. Gastrophrenic ligament

2. Lesser omentum

3. Gastrosplenic ligament

4. Falciform ligament

5. Greater omentum
questions.solution:
The structure marked is dorsal mesentery and gastrophrenic ligament, gastrosplenic ligament and greater omentum are the derivatives. 

Mesenteries are double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.

Dorsal mesentery: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut have a dorsal mesentery. This connects the organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. It has the following special names in different regions:

  • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach 
  • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
  • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
  • Mesoappendix- appendix
  • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon
  • Sigmoid mesocolon- sigmoid colon
  • Gastrosplenic ligament (stomach to the spleen), lienorenal ligament (spleen to the left kidney), and gastrophrenic ligament (stomach to diaphragm) are derived from the dorsal mesentery.

Ventral mesentery: Only the foregut has a ventral mesentery. It is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum. The ventral mesentery is derived from the septum transversum. When the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, it divides the ventral mesentery into 2 parts:

  • Lesser omentum- extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver
  • Ligaments of the liver- all ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments), except ligamentum teres

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of gastritis presents with fever and weight loss. Endoscopy revealed diffuse mucosal thickening with ulceration in the stomach. The biopsy showed dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands. Cytogenetic studies reveal t(11;18). What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and biopsy showing dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands and cytogenetics study showing t(11;18) are suggestive of gastric MALToma.

MALToma is a lymphoma arising from mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is actually extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of gut mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is usually primary GI lymphoma (4% of gastric lymphoma); of non-Hodgkin’s B cell type. The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in MALT lymphomas is t(11;18). The most common site is the stomach. Helicobacter pylori infection is the causative agent commonly. MALToma can be associated with Type B symptoms like fever, night sweats and weight loss.

Histologically, MALTomas show dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create lymphoepithelial lesions. MALTomas express B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, but not CD5 or CD10.

On endoscopy, MALToma shows diffuse mucosal thickening which may ulcerate. Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics has shown to be an effective therapy for MALToma. Surgical resection has no role in the treatment unless there has been some complication like perforation or uncontrollable bleeding.

Other options

Option B: Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of stomach malignancies as it constitutes more than 90% of all gastric cancers. Based on the gross appearance, it is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse type, which is characterized by gastric wall thickening due to infiltrates
  • Intestinal type, which is associated with malignant masses composed of glandular structures

Option C: Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the C-MYC gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

Option D: Gastrointestinal tumor (GIST) is a mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. Most GISTs have a gain of function mutation in KIT. The microscopic appearance of GIST consists of thin elongated cells (spindle cell type), or plumper, epithelial-appearing cells (epithelioid type). Most commonly an admixture of the two is seen.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva, and stridor is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and thumb sign on the x-ray is acute epiglottitis.

Causative organisms are Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, drooling, and progressing respiratory obstruction. Stridor appears late and indicates near-complete respiratory obstruction. Child sits in tripod position to relieve the obstruction.

Laryngoscopy shows large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis. X-ray of lateral view of neck shows thumb sign. Management is to give antibiotics and emergency endotracheal intubation is done as required.

Other options:

Option-A: Retropharyngeal abscess is often polymicrobial caused by streptococcus, staphylococcus, and anaerobes. Clinical features include fever, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice, and trismus. Management is by giving intravenous antibiotics with or without surgical drainage.

Option-B: Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly presenting with inspiratory stridor which is low-pitched and exacerbated by crying or feeding. Symptoms usually appear within the first two weeks of life. Most symptoms resolve spontaneously as the child and airway grow.

Option C: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection. Clinical features include low-grade fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Steeple sign is seen on the x-ray due to subglottic narrowing. If the child is hypoxic, immediate airway management is done.

Steeple sign in croup appears as in the image below:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign

questions.text: A study about mean cholesterol levels was conducted in three different villages of Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. Health workers were sent and data was collected. The mean cholesterol levels of each village were taken and compared. Identify the study design used:
questions.solution:
The correct study design described for the given scenario would be a cross-sectional study.

A cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. Here, data is collected at a single point to examine the relationship between variables (in this case, cholesterol levels) across different groups (villages in Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu). Each village's mean cholesterol levels are measured and compared, but there is no follow-up or intervention, which is characteristic of a cross-sectional design.

 It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do not establish the time sequence.

Other options:

Option A: In case-control, we compare individuals with a disease (cases) to those without (controls), typically looking retrospectively at exposure. This study doesn't do that.

Option B: In the cohort, we follow a group of people over time to observe outcomes based on exposures. There's no mention of follow-up over time in this study.

Option D: A field trial involves administering interventions to participants in their natural environment (outside of clinical settings) to evaluate the effect of the intervention on specific outcomes. In this case, the study is observational and does not include any interventions, so it wouldn't be classified as a field trial.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with gait disturbance. On examination, the Romberg test was positive, and pupillary reflex was absent. Past history is significant for untreated painless genital ulcer. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this case?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tertiary syphilis/ neurosyphilis. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would be the best investigation as the diagnosis is neurosyphilis.

Tertiary syphilis occurs months to years after infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients usually present with the following clinical findings:

  • Gummas: It is the most common manifestation. These are the granulomas involving the skin, bones (perforated nasal septum), liver, and spleen.
  • Cardiovascular manifestations occur due to end arteritis of the vasa vasorum supplying the aorta. This results in aortitis, aortic regurgitation, and aortic aneurysm.
  • Neurosyphilis
    • End arteritis of cerebral vessels results in meningovascular syphilis. Patients present with symptoms of cerebral infarcts like aphasia, hemiparesis, and visual loss.
    • The actual destruction of neurons by the treponemes results in:
      • Tabes dorsalis affect the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Bowel and bladder disturbances, foot slap, impotence, ataxia, loss of position, and vibration sense, resulting in a positive Romberg test.
      • Involvement of neurons of the cerebral cortex results in Argyll-Robertson pupil (reacts to accommodation but not to light), illusions, delusions, hallucinations, slurring of speech, and reduced memory.

The CSF VDRL test is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis. It has high specificity.

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G or aqueous procaine penicillin G is used for the treatment of neurosyphilis.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: A 24 yr-old-man is brought to the hospital by his wife with the complaint that under stressful situations the patient's behavior completely changes. He behaves like a child and also believes that he is a 7-year-old boy named Tom. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical vignette, the most likely diagnosis is dissociative identity disorder.

Dissociative identity disorder is marked by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states. It was previously called multiple personality disorder. It is thought to arise due to childhood trauma, most frequently associated with physical or sexual abuse during early childhood.

The identities or personality states are called, alters, self­ states, or alter identities. Each has its own pattern of perceiving and thinking about the environment and self. Most affected patients also suffer from a mood disorder, generally one of the depression spectrum disorders. Obsessive-compulsive personality traits are also frequently associated. Psychotherapy and hypnosis are used to treat the condition. Antidepressants can be used for the stabilization of mood. In some patients with refractory mood disorders, electroconvulsive therapy can be tried.

Other options:

Option A: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

Option B: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder and is of two types. Bipolar I disorder requires at least one episode of mania for diagnosis. Bipolar II disorder is characterized by at least one major depressive episode (for at least 2 weeks) and a hypomanic episode (for at least 4 days) each.

Option D: Depersonalization is the feeling of not being themselves or that something has changed. There is a feeling of unreality or detachment from one's whole self or from some aspects of self.

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)

questions.text: A patient presents to a surgeon with a complaint of bleeding per rectum. On examination, the following finding was seen. The mass did not reduce spontaneously or manually. This presentation is classified as:
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the image showing a reddish mass protruding out of the anal canal that does not reduce spontaneously or manually is suggestive of grade IV internal hemorrhoids.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

  • Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improves with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.
  • Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Rubber band ligation involves pulling mucosa located 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloughing off of the mass in a few days. 
  • Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

1) Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

2) Open hemorrhoidectomy- artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. 

3) Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy- the hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucosal defect is then closed. The image below describes the procedure.

4) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation)- the hemorrhoids are pulled up and a purse-string suture is placed a few centimeters above the dentate line. Then, a circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence, however, it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with excision using an elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed.

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction was started on Bempedoic acid as an adjunct. This drug inhibits which of the following steps of cholesterol biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, which converts citrate to acetyl CoA.

Bempedoic acid is a newly approved pro-drug that lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting de-novo synthesis of cholesterol in the hepatocytes. The impermeable mitochondrial membrane does not allow the acetyl-CoA formed from pyruvate to be utilised for cholesterol synthesis. Therefore, citrate from the TCA cycle enters the cytoplasm, where it is cleaved by a cytoplasmic enzyme ATP citrate lyase into Acetyl CoA and oxaloacetate. This Acetyl Co-A is further converted to HMG CoA, which is a substrate for HMG CoA reductase targetted by statins.

This makes its action complementary to statins and is hence used as an adjunct in the management of Familial hypercholesterolemia and established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. 

The image below summarises the action of bempedoic acid in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the emergency with watery diarrhea. The diagnosis was made on stool cytotoxin assay. On colonoscopy, ulcers, plaque's and pseudo-membranes were visualized. Patient condition improved drastically after the use of metronidazole. CECT finding is given below. What is the name of the sign seen on CECT?
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign is seen on CT examinations of the abdomen and refers to the similarity between the thickened edematous wall of pseudomembranous colitis to that of an accordion. The appearance arises as a result of oral contrast being trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudo-membranes formed on the luminal surface of the colon.

Pseudomembranous colitis is a severe form of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI), typically caused by prolonged use of antibiotics such as cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin, which disrupt the gut flora, causing a spectrum of disease ranging from watery diarrhoea to fulminant, life-threatening colitis. The bacteria release toxins that damage the colon, causing diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever, and the formation of whitish-yellow plaques (pseudomembranes). Diagnosis is made through stool tests for toxins or bacteria. Risk factors include advanced age, poor hygiene, and gastrointestinal surgery.

questions.text: An elderly female presented to the OPD with a rapidly progressive swelling in the thyroid region with complaints of stridor and hoarseness of voice. The histopathological findings suggest anaplastic thyroid carcinoma with the involvement of carotid sheath. Identify the sign and a close differential to this case.
questions.solution:
In a patient with anaplastic carcinoma thyroid, as in the given case, the involvement of the carotid sheath can cause absent carotid pulsations, described as Berry’s sign, which is seen in anaplastic carcinoma and Riedel’s thyroiditis.

Anaplastic carcinoma thyroid is an undifferentiated aggressive carcinoma common in elderly females. The symptoms include stridor, hoarseness of voice due to tracheal obstruction, dysphagia, absent carotid pulsation, and Horner’s syndrome(infiltration of the cervical sympathetic chain). FNAC is diagnostic. All of them are stage IV. Tracheostomy and isthmectomy relieve obstruction. Treatment is external radiotherapy and adriamycin as chemotherapy. 

Riedel’s thyroiditis is a rare benign entity wherein thyroid tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue that infiltrates the capsule into surrounding muscles, paratracheal tissues, and carotid sheath(Berry’s sign).

The swelling has an irregular surface, stony hard consistency, and stridor and is common in males. The close differential is Anaplastic carcinoma thyroid. Treatment is isthmectomy followed by L-thyroxine replacement. High-dose steroid is used. 

Other options: 

Option A: Pemberton sign is positive in Retrosternal goitre. The patient is asked to raise the arm above the shoulder level. Dilated veins are seen over the neck and upper chest wall. This is due to the compression of structures like SVC and trachea. 

Option B: Kocher’s sign is positive in thyrotoxicosis. When the clinician places his hands on the patient’s eyes and lifts them higher, his upper lid springs up more quickly than the eyebrows.

Option D: A solitary thyroid nodule while examined by Pizzillo’s method, the Trail sign is found to be positive when there is a tracheal deviation to the opposite side. This is also confirmed by the three-finger test, auscultation test, and X-ray neck.

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.
