questions.text: A male patient presents with a genital ulcer. The smear from the lesion shows bacilli, arranged as shown in the image, which stains more on the poles than the cytoplasm. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of the ulcer seen in this patient?

choices.text: Painful genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymph nodes
Painless beefy genital ulcer with pseudobubos
Painful indurated ulcer with painful inguinal lymph nodes
Painful non-indurated ulcer with painful inguinal lymph nodes

questions.solution:
The causative organism of the genital ulcer, which shows a school of fish arrangement in the image, is Haemophilus ducreyi. It causes chancroid, or soft sore, characterized by a painful, non-indurated ulcer and painful inguinal lymph nodes.

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted disease that is largely localised, producing non-indurated irregular ulcers and spreading to regional lymph nodes, causing their painful enlargement. Infection confers no immunity to the host.

H. ducreyi is an ovoid bacillus that is gram-negative but may show gram positivity and bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) arranged in end-to-end pairs or chains showing a school of fish or railroad track morphology.

It requires only the X factor to form small, grey translucent colonies and can be grown on fresh clotted rabit blood, chick embryo’s chorioallantoic membrane, chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum with vancomycin. It is susceptible to sulfonamides, erythromycin, cotrimoxazole or ceftriaxone. 

Organisms that show bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) include Klebsiella granulomatis, Haemophilus ducreyi Yersinia pestis, Burkholderia pseudomallei, and V. parahaemolyticus. The below image shows the safety pin appearance of the bacteria.

Klebsiella granulomatis may also cause preferential staining at the poles. However, it does not exhibit a "school of fish" appearance, as seen in this case. It causes painless, red, beefy ulcers with pseudobubos (Option B).

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: Which of the following components is a part of the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Literacy rate is one of the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). All other options are components of the human development index (HDI).

Physical Quality of Life Index measures three indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Life expectancy at age one
  • Literacy rate

For each indicator, the performance of a country is rated from 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best performance. PQLI is calculated by taking the average of the three indicators, with equal weightage for each of the indicators. 

The index is used for international and national comparisons. It measures the results of social, economic, and political policies. The PQLI does not take into account the per capita income of the country. Therefore, the Middle Eastern countries that are rich, have a lower PQLI compared to Sri Lanka or the state of Kerala in India.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

questions.text: A first year PG resident picks up the given instrument to examine a patient. Which of the following statements about it is correct?

choices.text: Image formed is virtual and erect
Area of field in focus is around 8 disc dioptre (DD)
Not possible to examine through hazy media.

questions.solution:
The given image is of an indirect ophthalmoscope and the correct statement about it is that area of field in focus is around 8 disc dioptre (DD).

The principle of indirect ophthalmoscopy is to make the eye highly myopic. Light is transmitted from the headset to the fundus through a condensing lens held at the focal point of the eye, providing an inverted image that is observed through a stereoscopic viewing system.

  • A convex lens is used, commonly +20D.
  • The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified.
  • It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions.

questions.text: A patient with a history of RTA came with acute blood loss. The House surgeon in the casualty gave excessive IV fluids, now the patient has tachycardia. Which of the following is true regarding this reflex?

choices.text: Elicited by stretch receptors of the ventricle
Vasomotor center is located in the pons

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with tachycardia after infusion of excessive intravenous fluids is suggestive of the Bainbridge reflex. This reflex prevents the pooling of blood in the vessels.

The stretch receptors of the atria (option A) that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves (option D), in response to above normal circulatory volume, to the vasomotor centre of the brain present in the medulla oblongata. (option B).

Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Thus, this reflex helps prevent the pooling of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with confusion, petechiae, and acute kidney injury. She reported recent episodes of bloody diarrhoea a week ago. Lab findings show anaemia with schistocytes, severe thrombocytopenia, elevated LDH, and indirect bilirubin. Which finding would most strongly suggest a diagnosis of TTP over HUS?

choices.text: Neurological symptoms in addition to renal involvement
Presence of fragmented red cells on peripheral smear

questions.solution:
Neurological symptoms, such as confusion, seizures, and headaches, are more characteristic of TTP and help distinguish it from HUS.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits to form at various sites in the circulation. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

TTP is more common in patients with HIV infection and in pregnant women, and ADAMTS13 activity levels of <10% are diagnostic of TTP. 

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a condition characterised by microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.  It is preceded by an episode of diarrhoea, often hemorrhagic. It commonly affects children up to 5 years of age. The disease is often linked to a preceding gastrointestinal infection caused by Shiga toxin-producing strains like E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae.

Other options:

Option B: LDH is elevated in both TTP and HUS due to microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (MAHA), which causes cell destruction and tissue damage. 

Option C: A history of gastrointestinal symptoms is more suggestive of HUS and TTP, on the other hand, it may not involve preceding GI symptoms and is more commonly associated with neurological and systemic symptoms.

Option D: The presence of schistocytes (fragmented red cells) on a peripheral blood smear indicates MAHA, a feature seen in both TTP and HUS. Schistocytes confirm hemolysis but do not help distinguish between TTP and HUS specifically.

Image showing schistocytes and helmet cells due to MAHA

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with recurrent respiratory infections, bilateral nasal polyps, and chronic diarrhea with bulky, greasy stools. His sweat chloride level is 65 mEq/l. Which of the following acid-base abnormality is likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of recurrent respiratory infections, nasal polyps, and chronic diarrhea with bulky, greasy stools with positive sweat chloride test is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Metabolic alkalosis is likely to be seen in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Cystic fibrosis(CF) patients may develop contraction alkalosis due to excessive sweat sodium chloride losses which lead to extracellular fluid (ECF) volume contraction and chloride depletion. Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis is seen. Another mechanism is by abnormal ENaC functioning at the level of the kidney in CF patients may cause deficient renal HCO3− excretion.

Cystic fibrosis/Mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. 

Diagnostic tests:
1. Immunoreactive trypsinogen for newborn screening of cystic fibrosis.
2. Sweat chloride test: Increased chloride concentration >60 mEq/L is diagnostic.
3. Genetic testing for CFTR gene mutations is the gold standard and should be done for all cases.
4. Nasal transepithelial potential difference can be estimated in equivocal cases.

Diagnostic criteria:
Presence of

  • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
  • Positive newborn screening or
  • A sibling with cystic fibrosis.

Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by

  • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
  • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
  • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis:

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
    • Villous adenoma
    • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
  • Renal loss
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Posthypercapnic states
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome

Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):

  • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
  • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
  • Gastric losses in achlorhydria

Miscellaneous:

  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman's syndrome

questions.text:
A male patient was given anesthesia for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed there was a masseter muscle spasm in the patient. His vitals are given below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
  • Pulse rate - 134/min
  • Blood pressure - 150/90 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate - 28/min
  • Temperature - 102ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of masseter muscle spasm with hyperthermia and elevated blood pressure suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The least likely drug to cause this condition is atracurium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic condition, seen on exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. This sudden release of calcium can result in sustained muscle contraction by removing the inhibition of troponin. This leads to increased oxygen consumption, and increased CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Drugs known to trigger this condition include: 

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine.

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and is not implicated in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the primary health center for advice on contraception. She was advised to use the contraceptive provided under the Antara program. The dosage of the drug used in this contraceptive is_____.

I.M: Intramuscular
questions.solution:
The Antara program provides injectable contraceptive MPA (Medroxyprogesterone acetate). The dosage of the drug is 150 mg I.M., every 3 months. 

It acts by inhibiting ovulation, cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration, and endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken anytime after regular menstruation or after 6 weeks of delivery or immediately after abortion. Injectable contraceptives can be given up to 2 weeks prior to the due date to up to 4 weeks after the post-due date.

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for a rapid return to fertility.

Disadvantages are:

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light/heavy bleeding/amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
  • A slight loss in bone mineral density during the first 2 years of use.

This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30oC).

Antara [Injectable contraceptive depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)] and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government of India under its Mission Parivar Vikas. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
A patient with long-standing CSOM developed a fever with chills and rigor. On examination, there is edema over the posterior part of the mastoid region. Name the sign.

CSOM - Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media
questions.solution:
In a patient with long-standing CSOM who developed fever with chills and rigor, with edema over the posterior part of the mastoid region, indicates lateral sinus thrombophlebitis and the sign is referred to as Griesinger's sign.

Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis is characterized by several clinical features, including hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors due to septicemia, resembling malaria but with irregular fever patterns. Patients may experience headaches that start mild due to a peri-sinus abscess but can become severe as intracranial pressure rises from venous obstruction.

A key sign is Griesinger’s sign, where edema over the mastoid occurs due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein, impeding venous drainage. Additionally, papilloedema can develop from obstructed venous return, particularly with right sinus thrombosis, and tenderness along the jugular vein may indicate thrombophlebitis extension into that vein, often accompanied by inflammation and enlarged jugular lymph nodes, potentially leading to torticollis.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture
  • CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
          1)Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
          2)Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with petrosistis present with the characteristic syndrome called the Gradenigo syndrome which is a triad of: 

  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media
  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve (VI)  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve (V) involvement

Option C: Crowe-Beck sign- Pressure on the jugular vein of the healthy side produces engorgement of retinal veins (seen by ophthalmoscopy) and supraorbital veins. Engorgement of veins subsides on the release of pressure.

Option D: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. The patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old asymptomatic male was reported to have a congenital defect as shown in the image. What should be the ideal line of management?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds suggestive of a diagnosis of Pancreas divisum. Conservative management would be done in asymptomatic patients.

Pancreas divisum results from the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds, due to which, the tail, body, and part of the head of the pancreas drain through the small accessory duct of Santorini rather than the main duct of Wirsung. It may be associated with recurrent pancreatitis.  It is also the most common pancreatic developmental anomaly.

Most people with a pancreas divisum are asymptomatic, but if symptomatic, it presents with chronic abdominal pain, acute or chronic pancreatitis. The diagnosis can be arrived at by MRCP, EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injection of secretin if necessary.

In asymptomatic patients, usually conservative management is done and any intervention is not required. In patients with recurrent pancreatitis, an endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgical intervention may also involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or even resection of the pancreatic head.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child was brought to the OPD with a history of failure to thrive and poor weight gain. Characteristic hair findings are given. On examination, he also showed truncal hypotonia. The mineral deficient in this disease is a cofactor for?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the child with failure to thrive, poor weight gain, and truncal hypotonia along with an image showing kinky colorless, and sparse hair is suggestive of Menke's disease. The mineral deficient is copper, a co-factor for the enzyme tyrosinase.

Menkes disease is a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. It is caused by a defective lysyl oxidase enzyme. This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e. copper due to a defect in the ATP7A(not ATP7B) gene on chromosome X, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

The condition primarily affects males and manifests with non-specific symptoms at birth, such as hypoglycemia, hypothermia, prolonged jaundice, and cephalohematoma. By two months, typical signs appear, including kinky, light-colored, easily breakable hair, dry skin, and progressive neurological decline, with features like seizures and hypotonia. Additional findings include arterial tortuosities, characteristic facial features (micrognathia, blue iris), and cutis laxa.

Investigations reveal low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels. Neuroimaging, such as MRI or MRA of the brain, typically shows cerebral atrophy. The diagnosis is confirmed through genetic testing. Subcutaneous or intravenous copper-histidine is the most effective treatment.

Note :

ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive (Chromosome 13)

Other options:

Option A: Arginase plays a role in the urea cycle and uses manganese.

Option B: Succinate dehydrogenase is used in the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain, it uses iron and FAD.

Option C: Xanthine oxidase is involved in purine metabolism, this enzyme requires molybdenum. 

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A multigravida woman presents to you with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaining of mild intermittent lower abdominal pain and spotting per vaginum. Examination reveals a soft abdomen with no guarding and rigidity. The urine pregnancy test is positive and the hCG level is 5000 IU/L. USG shows a mass on the left adnexa measuring 5cm x 4cm with positive fetal cardiac activity. What is the next step given that the female does not want any further pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Salpingectomy is the management for this patient as it is a case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy with a complete family with gestational sac > 4cm and fetal cardiac activity present. (Option A)

The given clinical scenario of a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea with occasional spotting per vaginum, intermittent mild abdominal pain with UPT positive, and a left adnexal mass of 5 cm x 4cm with positive fetal cardiac activity suggests a tubal ectopic pregnancy. Examination findings of a soft abdomen with no guarding, rigidity, and a hemodynamically stable condition suggest an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Findings suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy include -

  • Hemodynamically unstable in the form of tachycardia and hypotension.
  • Abdominal distension, rebound tenderness
  • Localizing signs of peritonitis such as guarding, rigidity
  • History of shoulder tip pain(diaphragmatic irritation due to bleeding in the peritoneum), syncopal attack and urge to defecate(pooling of blood in the Pouch of Douglas compressing the rectum)

Criteria for medical management with intramuscular injection of methotrexate single dose (50mg/m2) include -

  • Low initial serum beta-hCG level (Less than 5,000 IU/L)
  • Small ectopic pregnancy size (Less than 4 cm)
  • Absent fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable

Note - If cardiac activity is present with a sac diameter < 3.5 cm, medical management can be done but it poses higher chances of failure.

Surgical management is done by salpingectomy only regardless of whether primi or multigravida in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Whereas in the case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy, if the female desires future pregnancy or the family is incomplete with a gestational sac < 5cm then salpingostomy or linear salpingostomy is done, and if the family is complete or gestational sac > 5cm then salpingectomy is indicated.

Indications of surgical management are - 

  • Criteria for medical management are not met.
  • Persistent fetal cardiac activity.
  • Cases where beta hCG levels are not decreasing despite medical therapy.

Expectant management is where only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution. Its indications are:

  • Initial serum hCG level < 1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestational sac size less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS.
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS.

questions.text: A child was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of excessive watering and photophobia in an infant and the given image with corneal enlargement and haze suggest a likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma and Trabeculotomy with Trabeculectomy is the treatment of choice in hazy cornea.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) is caused by impaired aqueous outflow due to a maldeveloped anterior chamber angle.

It can be classified as

  • True congenital glaucoma - IOP is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma - manifests before 3 years of age.
  • Juvenile glaucoma (least common) - IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinically, the child presents with lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm.

PCG may also present with:

  • Corneal haze (due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP)
  • Buphthalmos (a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP before 3 years of age). The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Haab striae (curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane)
  • Corneal scarring
  • Optic disc cupping

Evaluation is done under general anesthesia. Initially, IOP measurement is performed (10–12  mmHg is normal). A corneal diameter measuring greater than 12 mm is highly suggestive of congenital glaucoma in an infant under the age of 1 year.

Management of congenital glaucoma:

Medical management is not very effective, therefore surgery is the mainstay of treatment. However, drugs like timolol, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are used to lower IOP until the surgery is taken up.

Surgical procedures:

  • Goniotomy: It is done in cases where the cornea is clear.  Under gonioscopic control, a surgical incision is made at the angle midway between the root of the iris and the Schwalbe line.
  • Trabeculotomy: This is useful when corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle or in cases where goniotomy has failed. After raising conjunctival flap, a scleral incision is made, Schlemm's canal is exposed, and an opening is made using a trabeculotome.
  • Trabeculotomy with Trabeculectomy is a standard procedure done in cases where there is corneal opacification or corneal edema.
  • Glaucoma drainage devices (GDD) are required in incalcitrant cases.

Trabeculoplasty is not done in congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: Amyloid deposited in senile cardiac amyloidosis is:
questions.solution:
Amyloid deposited in senile cardiac amyloidosis is transthyretin (TTR).

Cardiac amyloidosis can result from systemic amyloidosis (e.g., myeloma or inflammation-associated) or it might be restricted to the heart as in elderly patients i.e. senile cardiac amyloidosis. The deposits are primarily composed of transthyretin (TTR), a liver-synthesized protein that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein. Mutations in transthyretin accelerate the disease progression. It typically causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, though it can also present as dilation, arrhythmias, or mimic ischemic or valvular disease, depending on the location of the amyloid deposits.

Other options :

Option A: AA amyloid is typically associated with chronic inflammatory conditions, like rheumatoid arthritis or infections, leading to reactive systemic amyloidosis(secondary amyloidosis) or hereditary amyloidosis like Familial Mediterranean fever.

Option C: Amyloid Light chain (AL) deposits are seen in multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell proliferations.

Option D: Beta-2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) amyloid is usually seen in patients undergoing long-term dialysis.

questions.text: Squatting leads to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur caused by
questions.solution:
Rapid squatting leads to a decrease in the intensity of murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

  • Loudest along the left sternal border
  • Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:
    • Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators
    • Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  
  • Decreases in intensity when there is
    • Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration
    • Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors
    • Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

questions.text: A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. On examination, decreased breath sounds and dull note on percussion is noted on the right side. A CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT scan showing the split pleura sign is suggestive of empyema.

Empyema is defined as a collection of pus in the pleural cavity. Empyema is usually associated with pneumonia but may also develop after thoracic surgery or thoracic trauma.

At the margins of the empyema, the pleura can be seen dividing into parietal and visceral layers, the split pleura sign. It is the most sensitive and specific sign on CT and is helpful in distinguishing an empyema from a peripheral lung abscess.

CT scan showing split pleura sign: 

Differentiating empyema from lung abscesses may be difficult sometimes. CT is useful to distinguish an empyema from a lung abscess. Radiologically, a thicker and more irregular wall, and destruction rather than compression of the underlying lung suggest abscess rather than empyema. Unlike empyema, lung abscess is caused by trans diaphragmatic extension of a liver abscess or by bronchopleural fistula.  Contrast-enhanced CT should be adopted to visualize the margins and any associated vascular or airway complications. CT findings of lung abscess are similar to radiographs, with thick-walled, discrete cavitating lesions containing fluid, with or without gas.

The below image shows a lung abscess as the thick-walled cavitary lesion in the right lung, The diffuse ground glass infiltrates present in both lungs represent pneumonia.

questions.text: At what age would a term newborn with normal growth and development and a birthweight of 3 kg be expected to reach around 12 kg?
questions.solution:
The term newborn with a birthweight of 3 kg and a normal growth and development will be expected to reach around 12 kg at 2 years of age as the birthweight becomes four times by 2 years.

A newborn loses 10% of the birth weight during the first few days after birth due to the loss of extracellular fluid, which is regained by 10 days in term neonates. After this, the rate of weight gain is around 20-40g/day for the first three months of life and around 400 g every month for the remaining part of the first year. Therefore, the approximate weight by age would be:

Age Weight (kg)
Birth 3
6 months 6 (doubles)
1 year 9 (triples)
2 years 12 (quadruples)
3 years 15 (5 times)
5 years 18 (6 times)
7 years 21 (7 times)
10 years 30 (10 times)

The average weight gain of the child is around 2 kg per year between 3 to 7 years and 3 kg per year till pubertal growth spurt begins.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic woman presented to the casualty with an infected foot ulcer, rapid pulse, and altered sensorium. She is started on IV fluids via wide-bore cannulas. Which of the following will not be the endpoint of resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Monitoring of blood pressure is not an endpoint of resuscitation. 

Resuscitation until the correction of global perfusion endpoints, i.e., base deficit, lactate, and mixed venous oxygen saturation (MVOS), is shown to improve mortality and morbidity.

Earlier, patients were resuscitated until clinical endpoints of resuscitation, like normal BP, pulse rate, and urine output, were achieved. But even when the vital signs returned to normal, the underperfusion was uncorrected. Such cases still manifested with persistent lactic acidosis and low MVOS. This is known as occult hypoperfusion.

Other options:

Option A: MVOS is the percentage saturation of oxygen returning to the heart from the body. It is a measure of oxygen delivery and extraction by the tissues. It is measured using blood from a central line. Normal values are 50–70%. Levels below 50% are seen in hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock. Levels of more than 70% are seen in distributive shock (sepsis).

Option C and D: Lactic acid is a product of anaerobic respiration. Patients with a base deficit of more than 6 mmol/L have high mortality. The degree of lactic acidosis and/or the base deficit is sensitive to detect shock and monitor response to treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following vaporisers contains the inhalational anaesthetic that produces seizure activity and is contraindicated in patients with a seizure disorder?
questions.solution:
The orange-coloured vaporiser (4) contains enflurane, causes seizures and is contraindicated in patients with a seizure disorder.

Enflurane is a colourless gas with a sweet odour and is primarily used for maintenance of anaesthesia as induction of anaesthesia is slower owing to its high blood: gas partition coefficient. It is known to reduce seizure threshold and is nephrotoxic. It can also lower arterial blood pressure and myocardial contractility and is an effective bronchodilator.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely present in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen are suggestive of gastric volvulus. Borchardt's triad will most likely be present in a case of gastric volvulus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A woman presented to the emergency department with acute onset nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain. Based on her lab parameters acute pancreatitis was suspected. A contrast-enhanced CT abdomen scan with neutral oral contrast media was advised to confirm the diagnosis.  Which of the following contrast media can be used in this study?
questions.solution:
Among the given option the neutral contrast that can be used in the contrast-enhanced CT abdomen scan is water.

There are three types of contrast media used in X ray / CT imaging studies - Positive, negative and neutral contrast.

Neutral contrast media are used to distend the bowel but they do not opacify the bowel. Common examples include water, oil emulsions or sugar solutions (e.g. mannitol, sorbitol, polyethylene glycol). However, neutral contrast media has difficulty visualizing extraluminal soft-tissue density lesions and bowel fistulas. 

Positive contrast agents are substances that increase the X-ray attenuation within the body, making the tissues or structures containing these agents appear whiter or brighter on the X-ray image. On oral administration, they opacify the bowel. Common examples of include iodinated compounds (Iohexol, Gastrografin etc.) and barium sulfate. 

Negative contrast agents decrease the X-ray attenuation within the body, making the tissues or structures containing these agents appear darker on the X-ray image. These agents are radiolucent, meaning they allow X-rays to pass through more easily than surrounding tissues. Air and carbon dioxide gas are common examples of negative contrast agents used in radiology.

questions.text: A first-year biochemistry student was conducting a lab test on proteins. He added nitric acid to a protein solution and heated it, resulting in the solution turning dark yellow as shown in the image below. This reaction is shown by a group of amino acids. Which among the following amino acid derivatives can give this reaction?
questions.solution:
The test described and image shown is of Xanthoproteic test, which detects the presence of aromatic amino acids (Phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan) in proteins. Melanin is derived from tyrosine, an aromatic amino acid, and retains the ability to react with nitric acid to produce the characteristic color change.

Other options

Option B: Citrulline is a non-aromatic amino acid and does not contain the necessary structure to undergo nitration by nitric acid, thus will not give a color change.

Option C: GABA is also a non-aromatic amino acid, derived from glutamate. 

Option D: Histamine is derived from histidine, even though it has an imidazole ring, it does not produce a positive result in the Xanthoproteic test since it lacks a benzene ring.

questions.text: A patient presented with cough, hemoptysis and chest pain. Sputum examination showed broad-based fungi. A drug ‘X’ was started for this patient which is a CYP3A4 inhibitor. Identify the site of action of this drug.
questions.solution:
The patient with cough, hemoptysis, chest pain and broad-based fungi on sputum examination has blastomycosis. The drug ‘X’, which is a CYP3A4 inhibitor, is most likely Itraconazole, and its mechanism of action is marked as 3 in the image, inhibition of biosynthesis of ergosterol from lanosterol.

Itraconazole is a triazole used systemically. It is both a substrate and inhibitor of CYP3A4. It is used in the management of invasive aspergillosis, blastomycosis, coccidioidomycosis, histoplasmosis, pseudallescheriasis, sporotrichosis, ringworm and onychomycosis. It is generally safe when there are no interacting drugs, but it may cause diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, nausea, and anorexia. The drug also has an FDA-boxed warning for serious side effects like QT prolongation, heart failure, negative inotropic effects, hepatotoxicity, hypertriglyceridemia, and hypokalemia, which may warrant drug discontinuation and is contraindicated in pregnancy. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who is a known case of peripheral arterial disease comes with complaints of pain over the calf and a leg ulcer. His ankle-brachial pressure index was measured and the value was 2. What does it signify?
questions.solution:
The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) value of 2 is suggestive of calcified vessels.

The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is taken as the numerator, with the highest pressure in the brachial artery being the denominator. It can be used as an initial, bedside test for peripheral arterial disease. 

Interpretation:

  • >0.9 to < 1.4 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion.
  • <0.4 –Chronic limb-threatening ischemia(may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene)
  • > 1.4 - Calcified vessels

Medial sclerosis and calcification of the arterial wall cause artificially high ABPI readings of  >1.4. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM).

Digital arteries in the toe are rarely affected by sclerosis. Hence, toe–brachial pressure index (TBI) in combination with ABPI is a more reliable tool for the detection of significant large-vessel steno-occlusive disease in patients with DM. A TBI value of less than 0.6 suggests a significant arterial lesion.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is evaluated as a part of the first-trimester aneuploidy screening test for Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is evaluated as a part of the combined first-trimester aneuploidy screening test.

First-trimester Aneuploidy Screening at 11-14 weeks of gestation includes:

  • β-HCG
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal translucency scan  

Fetal trisomy 21 causing Down syndrome has higher levels of hCG and lower PAPP-A. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both hCG and PAPP-A are lower.

Second-trimester aneuploidy screening at 15-21 weeks includes

  • β-HCG        
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)         
  • Unconjugated estriol        
  • Inhibin A

questions.text: During your visit to the village, your adopted family does not have lights at their home. As per your knowledge on National health programs, which among the following programs can help them?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate program which can help the family would be Ujala.

The Ujala Scheme (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs and Appliances for All) is the largest domestic lighting project in the world, launched under the Ministry of Power. It aims at promoting the use of energy-efficient LED bulbs in every household in the country.

The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. (Option B)

The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crores of free cooking LPG connections to all families below the poverty line till 2019. (Option C)

INSPIRE strategy is a set of 7 evidence-based strategies introduced to select, implement, monitor, and evaluate effective policies, programs, and services to prevent and respond to violence against children. (Option D)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient experienced a complete loss of vision following a functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic ethmoidal sinusitis. Which of the following air cells are in close anatomical proximity to the structure most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure most likely injured in this patient is the optic nerve and the Onodi cell is in close proximity to it.

Onodi cell is an anatomical variant, in which the posterior ethmoidal cells enlarge and extend into the sphenoid bone laterally and superior to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimetres from their anterior wall.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell or the sphenoethmoidal cell.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) which is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus or orbital floor above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A neonate with vertebral and limb deformities was unable to pass meconium in the last 48 hours. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension with an anal dimple and Wangenstein's invertogram shows a low-lying defect.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is imperforate anus with VACTERL association (presence of vertebral and limb anomalies in addition to the anal atresia).

The neonate will present with an inability to pass meconium, abdominal distension, anal dimple, and sometimes passing meconium per urethra. It is divided into low intermediate and high lyings according to the Wingspread classification. Diagnosis is done using Wangenstein invertogram . Treatment is surgical.

Other options:

Option A: Hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition that occurs due to the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum. It is associated with Downs syndrome. Delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and severe chronic constipation are the features. Rectal examination shows a tight sphincter with an empty rectum. X-ray of the abdomen shows intestinal obstruction.

Option B: Meconium ileus is a condition, where thick meconium gets collected in the intestine and obstructs the lumen.  It is classically associated with cystic fibrosis. Features are intestinal obstruction, respiratory dysfunction, and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency with high salty sweat. X-ray shows calcified meconium pellets with air-fluid level (soap bubble appearance)

Option D:  Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus and occurs when a portion of the intestine twists around its blood supply. It shows features like abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and a tyre-like feel of the abdomen. The plain radiograph shows the pathognomic omega sign and coffee bean sign.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female visits the OPD with complaints of irregular menstruation, with her last menstrual period being two months back. On per-speculum examination, you find a bluish hue of the vagina and vestibule. Which of the following signs may additionally be observed on per speculum examination?
questions.solution:
The patient with irregular menstruation and an LMP of 2 months back with a bluish hue in the vagina (Chadwick sign) is exhibiting signs of early pregnancy. Out of the given signs of pregnancy, Goodell's sign is a cervical change, i.e. softening of the cervix, which can be observed on per speculum examination. Hegar's, Piscaceks and Palmer's are uterine signs elicited by bimanual examination. 

The objective signs of early pregnancy in the cervix and uterus are:

Sign Feature Seen in
Jacquemier's/Chadwick The dusky hue of the vaginal wall 8th week
Osiander's Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices 8th week
Goodell's Softening of cervix 6th week
Hegar's Bimanual examination with two fingers in the anterior fornix and fingers of the other hand behind uterus, abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to oppose below the body of the uterus, which is due to softening of the isthmus. 6-10 weeks
Palmer's Rhythmic uterine contraction on bimanual examination 4-8 weeks
Von Braun-fernwald's Irregular softening and enlargement of uterine fundus 5-8 weeks
Piskacek's One half of the uterus is firmer than the other half in case of lateral implantation 7-8 weeks
Ladin's Softening in the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly 6th week
Placental/Hartman's Cyclical bleeding at the time of implantation up to 12 weeks

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a blurring of vision. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is the earliest manifestation of your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical case and histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy. An increase in glomerular filtration rate(GFR) is the earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy.

It occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Increased GFR
  • Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin)Diagnostic marker to detect early diabetic nephropathy
  • Indicator of long-term cardiovascular disease
  • Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin)
  • End-stage renal disease

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

1. Glomerular lesions:

  1. Capillary basement membrane thickening
  2. Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
  3. Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease

2. Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis

3. Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Image showing natural history of diabetic nephropathy

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic process and cycle of various countries.  In which stages of the demographic cycle would he observe a stationary population?
questions.solution:
The population remains stationary in stages 1 and 4 in the demographic cycle.

Stage 1 - This stage is also known as high-stationary. The population remains stationary due to very high birth and death rates that cancel each other out. India was is in this stage until 1920.

Stage 4 - This stage is also known as low-stationary. The population remains stationary due to very low birth and death rates that cancel each other out.  Countries like the United Kingdom, Denmark, Sweden, and Belgium were in this stage in 1980-85.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text:
You have received a water sample, and test reports are given below. Which of the following methods can be recommended for treating the given water sample?
TEST Observed Permissible
pH 7.5 6.5-7.5
Overall hardness 5 mEq/L <1 mEq/L
Calcium Sulfate salts 3 mEq/L <0.1 mEq/L
Magnesium sulfate salts 1.6 mEq/L <0.1 mEq/L
Other salts 0.4 mEq/L Trace
Iron 0.1  mEq/L 0.1-1  mEq/L
Color Colorless Colorless
questions.solution:
In this case, the water sample has high levels of overall hardness, calcium sulfate, and magnesium sulfate, which exceed the permissible limits. This type of hardness is primarily due to the presence of calcium and magnesium salts, making it "permanent hardness" which has to be treated with base exchange process or ion exchange process.

Hardness of water can be:

  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

Base exchange process removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

Other options:

Option A and B: Boiling of water and addition of lime (Clark method) are methods to remove temporary hardness.

Option D: Activated carbon filtering is primarily used to remove organic compounds, chlorine, and odors and has no role in removing hardness of water.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: The reaction below summarises the formation of an end product of arginine. Identify the enzyme X.
questions.solution:
The enzyme X is nitric oxide synthase (NO synthase). Nitric oxide is synthesised from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalysed by NO synthase. 

Arginine, O2, and NADPH are substrates for cytosolic NO synthase. The co-enzymes of NO synthase include flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

There are three types of NO synthases. Two are Ca2+-calmodulin-dependent enzymes found in vascular endothelium and neural tissue, and one is a Ca2+-independent enzyme that is expressed in cells such as hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, and activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby decreases smooth muscle contraction.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and γ-interferon released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitters in the brain

Other options:

Option B: Arginase catalyzes the cleavage of L-arginine, forming urea and L-ornithine. Defective arginase leads to the inherited metabolic defect hyperargininemia.

Option C: Arginine-glycine amidinotransferase acts on glycine and arginine producing guanidinoacetate, which is a step in the biosynthesis of creatine and creatinine.

Option D: Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from Carbamoyl Phosphate in the urea cycle.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: While examining a stroke patient with UMN signs, the clinician performed the test given below and elicited a sign, which is equivalent to the babinski sign. Which is the sign elicited by the clinician?
questions.solution:
The sign elicited by the clinician which is equivalent to the Babinski sign is Hoffman’s sign.

To carry out this reflex after positioning your right index finger beneath the patient's middle finger's distal interphalangeal joint, apply a sudden downward flick to the nail. Check for any thumb reflex flexion in the patient.

Other options:

Option B: Bastian Burns sign is the loss of tone and deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs with preserved sensation in the presence of complete transection of the spinal cord above the level of conus medullaris.

Option C: Wartenberg sign refers to the involuntary abduction of the fifth finger due to ulnar nerve palsy, often seen in cases of ulnar neuropathy, 

Option D: Clasp knife sign is characterized by initial resistance to passive movement of a spastic limb, followed by a sudden release, commonly seen in upper motor neuron lesions due to corticospinal tract damage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a 2-day history of severe lower back pain radiating to both legs, asymmetric leg weakness, and new-onset urinary incontinence. Examination shows reduced perianal sensation , bilateral lower limb weakness (L4-S1) and diminished reflexes. As an intern, you suspect cauda equina syndrome. Which of the following findings does not fit in your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Early onset bladder incontinence is typical of Conus medullaris syndrome.  There is a relative sparing of bowel and bladder function with late-onset bladder involvement in cauda equina syndrome.

Cauda equina occurs due to compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord which is L1-L2. Common causes of cauda equina syndrome include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. Low back pain, asymmetrical loss of sensation, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, and saddle anesthesia (loss of sensation in the buttocks and perineal region) are common presenting symptoms. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen.

Related Pearl: Conus medullaris syndrome vs Cauda equina syndrome

Reflexes Knee jerk preserved, ankle jerk affected Both knee and ankle jerk affected
Sphincter dysfunction Urinary retention presents early in the disease course Urinary retention presents late in the disease course

questions.text: A young patient presented with fever and pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. USG shows a single abscess in the right lobe of the liver. Serology is positive for anti-amebic antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Positive serology for anti-amebic antibodies in a patient with fever and pain in the right upper quadrant suggests a diagnosis of amebic liver abscess. The most appropriate treatment for this is medical therapy with metronidazole and diloxanide.

Liver abscess is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of amebiasis. It can occur in patients with an evident history of colitis, but most commonly presents without any antecedent history related to the GIT. Patients present with fever, abdominal pain, and tender hepatomegaly. Heavy alcohol consumption is an important risk factor for the development of amebic liver abscesses.

Since USG abdomen cannot reliably differentiate between pyogenic and amebic liver abscesses, the mainstay of the diagnosis is in detecting anti-amebic antibodies in the blood by enzyme immunoassays. Examination of the stools for the organisms and the antigens is mostly negative. Image-guided aspiration of the fluid to detect amebic antigens may be used for diagnosis when serological studies are not useful.

The treatment is by metronidazole/tinidazole plus a luminal agent such as diloxanide/iodoquinol/paromomycin. The treatment is curative in >90% of the patients. Therapeutic needle aspiration (option A) has not been found to be any more beneficial than medical therapy. Needle aspiration of the abscess is thus reserved for cases where there is diagnostic uncertainty (testing for antigens) and those with a higher risk of rupture (>5 cm in diameter).

Pig-tail catheter insertion and drainage (option B) is done for the management of pyogenic liver abscess under the cover of antibiotics. Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR) therapy is done for the management of hydatid cyst of the liver.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with multiple purple lesions on his skin and oral cavity. The lesions have been progressively enlarging over the past few months. A biopsy of the lesions was taken, which is shown below. What type of virus is likely involved in the pathogenesis of the lesions described in this patient?
questions.solution:
The multiple purple lesions on his skin and oral cavity with the biopsy demonstrating sheets of whorled spindle cells along with prominent erythrocyte extravasation within slit-like spaces, in an HIV patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma. They are caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), a DNA-enveloped virus.

Here are a few examples of-

  • DNA Enveloped Viruses:
    • Hepatitis B virus (HBV)
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • DNA Non-Enveloped Viruses:
    • Adenoviruses
    • Parvoviruses
  • RNA Enveloped Viruses:
    • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
    • Hepatitis C virus (HCV)
    • Influenza virus
  • RNA Non-Enveloped Viruses:
    • Poliovirus
    • Coxsackievirus
    • Rotavirus

Kaposi sarcoma(KS) is a multifocal endothelial proliferation with low-grade malignant potential, strongly associated with AIDS and the gammaherpesvirus HHV-8. This virus plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of KS, which is commonly observed in immunocompromised individuals. The clinical presentation often includes progressively enlarging purple lesions on the skin and oral cavity, indicative of the disease.

Classic KS typically affects older men of Eastern European and Mediterranean descent and progresses through three clinical stages: the patch stage, the plaque stage, and the nodular/tumour stage. Histopathological examination reveals a circumscribed tumour nodule within the dermis, characterized by a dense, whorled arrangement of spindle cells. Erythrocyte extravasation within slit-like spaces is often prominent, accompanied by readily observable mitoses and eosinophilic globules.

In patients with AIDS, KS is considered an AIDS-defining illness and is the most prevalent malignancy associated with HIV infection. There is no definitive cure for KS, but it is highly radiosensitive, achieving complete responses in many cases. Treatment options include highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), which can lead to regression of lesions, as well as localized treatments such as excision, cryotherapy, and intra-lesional administration of agents like vinblastine and interferon-α2b.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the violaceous growth on the hard palate: 

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Classic

  • Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean origin
  • Not associated with HIV
  • Skin plaques and nodules

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a recurrent history of severe, constant abdominal pain with dysuria, pain in the limbs, and constipation. On examination, she had tachycardia and hypertension. Urine changes on exposure to light over some days are given. Her Porphobilinogen levels were high. The most likely deficient enzyme would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female patient with constant abdominal pain, dysuria and an image showing darkening of urine upon exposure to light and accumulation of porphobilinogen points towards a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria(AIP). This occurs due to a defect in Hydroxymethylbilane synthase or porphobilinogen deaminase.

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a hepatic porphyria inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase/hydroxymethylbilane synthase/uroporphyrinogen I synthase enzyme in heme synthesis. AIP is generally latent before puberty and is more common in women. 

AIP presents with neurovisceral symptoms and no cutaneous manifestations are seen. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom. Nausea, vomiting, constipation, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are seen. Tachycardia, hypertension, restlessness, tremors, and excess sweating are due to sympathetic overactivity. Other manifestations like seizures,  hallucinations and peripheral neuropathy can also occur.

Diagnosis can be made with increased level of plasma and urine ALA and PBG levels during an acute attack and remain high even after symptoms resolve. Urine on standing or exposure to light darkens due to oxidation of porphyrins.

Intravenous hematin as first-line treatment for acute attacks. Narcotic analgesia may be given for abdominal pain. Carbohydrate loading with intravenous glucose may be tried in milder attacks. Orthoptic liver transplant is curative in patients refractory to hemin therapy.

Note: Givosiran is a recently approved hepatic-targeted RNA interference (RNAi) therapy for acute hepatic porphyrias.

Other options: 

Option A: Porphobilinogen synthase is involved in the first step of porphyrin synthesis and its deficiency leads to  ALA dehydratase deficiency porphyria.

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency is associated with porphyria cutanea tarda, which presents with cutaneous symptoms and does not typically cause acute neurological symptoms.

Option C: Uroporphyrinogen synthase deficiency leads to congenital erythropoietic porphyria, which is also characterized by cutaneous symptoms.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with thiamine deficiency developed lactic acidosis. While on rounds, the senior resident explains the biochemical basis for the development of this condition. He says an important enzyme complex is principally affected. Which of the following is not a component of the enzyme complex being spoken of here?
questions.solution:
The enzyme complex affected in an alcoholic with lactic acidosis is the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex. Pyruvate kinase is not a part of this complex. 

The three enzyme components of the PDH complex:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

Thiamine is a cofactor of the pyruvate dehydrogenase component of the PDH complex. In thiamine deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited. Many alcoholics are thiamine deficient because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamine absorption. 

In the state of thiamine deficiency, there is an impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate then gets converted into lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase. This results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, leading to a state of lactic acidosis. 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is given as follows: Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited:

  • by its end products- acetyl CoA and NADH.
  • when there is adequate ATP available.
  • when fatty acids are being oxidized.
  • by arsenite and mercuric ions that react with the -SH groups. 
  • by a dietary deficiency of thiamine, e.g. chronic alcoholics and beriberi.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of persistent cough, chest pain, and intermittent hemoptysis. He recently travelled to Manipur and consumed undercooked freshwater crabs. His sputum is rusty in colour, and a chest X-ray reveals nodular and cystic shadows in the middle and lower lobes. What is seen in the sputum examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the 35-year-old man's symptoms and consumption of undercooked freshwater crabs strongly suggest an infection with Paragonimus westermani, the oriental lung fluke and operculated eggs are seen in the sputum examination of this patient.

The patient presents with a persistent cough, chest pain, and intermittent hemoptysis, which are classic symptoms associated with this parasitic infection. Given his consumption of undercooked freshwater crabs in Manipur—an area where P. westermani is endemic—these symptoms align with the pulmonary manifestations of the disease. Chest X-ray findings of nodular and cystic shadows in the middle and lower lobes further support the diagnosis, indicating the presence of cystic spaces in the lungs where the flukes reside.

P. westermani is a trematode that primarily infects the lungs of its definitive hosts, which include humans and various mammals. The adult flukes inhabit cystic spaces within the lung tissues, surrounded by a fibrous capsule. As they lay eggs, these eggs can be coughed up, leading to their presence in sputum.

The eggs of P. westermani (as shown below) are distinctive; they are operculated, golden-brown, and measure approximately 100 μm by 50 μm. 

In addition to pulmonary symptoms, they can lead to various complications, including peribronchial granulomas, bronchiectasis, and even extrapulmonary manifestations if the larvae migrate to other organs.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.
