questions.text: According to Casper’s dictum, which of the following is the correct ratio describing the rate of decomposition in air, water, and soil respectively?
questions.solution:
According to Casper’s dictum, the correct ratio of decomposition in air, water, and soil is 1 (Fastest):2:8 (Slowest). As Casper’s dictum states a body decomposes in air twice as rapidly as in water, and eight times as rapidly as in earth.

The rate and time of decomposition of the body, if denominated as 1 in air, will be 2 in water and 8 in soil. That means it is faster in air followed by water and soil. Hence the time taken for decomposition will be more in soil(8 times of air) followed by water(twice of air) followed by air so the order for time taken for decomposition will be soil > water > air.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with a 7-day history of a generalized pruritic rash, which started around the neck, without a history of cough, fever, or rhinorrhea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a large number of minute thin-walled vesicles on the trunk, consistent with a diagnosis of miliaria.

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis would involve specific inflammation in the pilosebaceous units.

Option B:  Infantile acne would have characteristic comedones, papules, and pustules. Moreover, the question states the boy is 4 years old. 

Option D: Candidal infections usually occur as macerated erythematous lesions in the intertriginous areas.  

Note: Milia, conversely, are tiny keratin‐filled, epithelial‐lined cysts that are not connected to the overlying skin.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: Which among the following tests is an example of a prospective screening method?

choices.text: Serum TSH level in a 2 day old neonate
Pap smear in 40 year old female
P24 antigen assay in a sex-worker

questions.solution:
P24 antigen assay in a sex worker is an example of prospective screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognised disease or defect in apparently healthy individuals using rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others' benefit People screened solely for their benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for Screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis, syphilis, yellow fever, etc
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with irregular periods, hirsutism, and infertility. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for this condition?

choices.text: At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
Ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound shows multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern, which is a feature of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). At least 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm should be seen on an ultrasound.

 USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • ≥12 follicles(Rotterdam criteria)/ ≥20 follicles(New criteria) each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume ≥10 ml
  • These ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on combined oral pills, as these pills alter the ovarian morphology.
  • A single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovarian syndrome:

National Institute of Health (NIH, 1990):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation

Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

questions.text: A premature infant was diagnosed to have necrotizing enterocolitis. An X-ray was taken and given below. What is the characteristic sign seen here?
questions.solution:
In the given image of an infant with necrotizing enterocolitis, we can see falciform ligament being outlined by the free abdominal gas, suggestive of falciform ligament sign seen in cases of pneumoperitoneum. 

Radiological signs in pneumoperitoneum:

Bowel-related signs:

  • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
  • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of the bowel or between two loops of the bowel and the abdominal wall.

Peritoneal ligament–related signs:

  • Football sign - the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in the massive pneumoperitoneum.
  • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments.
  • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.

Right upper quadrant signs:

  • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch
  • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline, seen on chest x-ray.
  • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
  • Hepatic edge sign
  • Lucent liver sign
  • Periportal free gas sign

Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm infants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor. Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall). Gas may be sometimes visualized in the portal venous tree. NE cases complicated by perforation may show pneumoperitoneum on abdominal x-ray. 

Other options:

Option A: The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

Option B: The double bubble sign is seen as two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum on x-ray. it is seen in the case of duodenal atresia. Neonates usually present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention.

Option D: The string of beads appearance is seen in intestinal obstruction.  In distal small bowel obstruction, the small bowel is fluid-filled and bubbles of gas are trapped between the valvulae conniventes, producing a chain of bubbles. giving a "string of beads" appearance.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 69-year-old patient with a history of RTA was admitted to the ICU. He has spontaneous but irregular breathing. ECG showed no abnormalities. The intensivist suspect's injury to the brainstem. Where is the lesion in the brainstem?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a patient with RTA with spontaneous but irregular breathing suggests the lesion at 3( transection midway between pons and medulla).

A transection between the medulla and the pons makes breathing irregular because the apneustic center's influence on the dorsal group of neurons is gone.

The pacemakers of normal breathing, neurons of the pre-Botzinger complex are located in the medulla. Dorsal and ventral groups of respiratory neurons are also present in the medulla. The dorsal group generates the inspiratory impulses independent of any other input into the brainstem. The ventral group is inactive during normal quiet breathing but provides expiratory signals to abdominal muscles during forceful expiration.

The impulses generated by the dorsal group are initially irregular. They are made regular by the input from the apneustic center located in the lower pons. The apneustic center itself is under inhibitory control of the pneumotaxic center, located in the upper part of the pons.

Other options

Option A: Lesion at 1(complete transection above pons), regular breathing continues if vagi is intact. If vagi is cut regular breathing continues but the depth of inspiration increases.


Option B: Lesion at 2(transection at the mid-pontine level) removes the influence of the pneumotaxic center on the apneustic center. If the vagi are intact, this results in regular, deep breathing. If the vagi are also cut, it leads to prolonged inspiratory effort, known as apneusis.


Option D: Lesion at 4(transection below the medulla) stops all spontaneous breathing because the inspiratory signals from the dorsal group are not able to act.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of pulmonary tuberculosis came with complaints of chronic right hip pain and stiffness which worsened at night. Which feature is not a part of  Phemister’s triad used in the radiological diagnosis of tuberculous arthropathy?
questions.solution:
Subchondral sclerosis is not a part of Phemister’s triad.

The Phemister triad refers to three radiographic features seen classically with tuberculous arthropathy. It includes

  • Juxta articular osteopenia
  • Reduced joint space
  • Peri articular erosions

Subchondral sclerosis is more likely a feature of osteoarthritis. It refers to denser area of bone just under the cartilage of the  joint, appearing as abnormally white bone along the joint line. Other features which are seen in osteoarthritis are joint space narrowing, subchondral cyst formation, and osteophyte formation.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male presents to the casualty with a history of coughing –up large quantities (around 200 ml/day) of blood. He gives a history of treatment completed pulmonary tuberculosis. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and his chest CT shows the following. A flexible bronchoscopy identified the site of bleeding. Which among the following will be the treatment option for this patient?

CTPA- CT-Pulmonary Angiography
questions.solution:
The given scenario and CT findings showing thickened and dilated airways, signet-ring sign with air bronchogram is suggestive of bronchiectasis with non-massive hemoptysis (massive> 600ml/day), and CTPA embolization will be the treatment option for this patient.

The first best step is to stabilize the patient by the administration of humidified oxygen, cough suppression, monitoring saturation, insertion of two large-bore intravenous cannulas, and administering intravenous vasopressin. In cases of non-massive hemoptysis, as in this case, a sequential approach can be adopted. A chest CT reveals the cause to be bronchiectasis. This is followed by a flexible bronchoscopy to localize the site of the bleed. CT pulmonary angiography is done, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic to embolise the bleeder.

Bronchiectasis is the abnormal dilatation of bronchi, which can occur in congenital conditions like cystic fibrosis and acquired conditions like suppurative pneumonia, pulmonary tuberculosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. It can cause chronic persistent cough with purulent sputum, pleuritic chest pain, acute massive hemoptysis, halitosis, and general debility. CT is a sensitive investigation. 

Other options:

Option A- Chest physiotherapy is an important aspect of treatment in patients with bronchiectasis as it assists drainage of bronchial secretions. However, it is not the management when the patient is having hemoptysis.

Option B- Surgical lobectomy is done in patients with localized bronchiectasis confined to a single lobe, especially in the apical region. Indications for surgical intervention include failure to control bleeding, fungus ball, lung abscess, and significant cavitary disease.

Option D-  Endoscopic banding is done for esophageal varices.

questions.text: As the medical officer of the primary health center (PHC), you are tasked with setting up a camp to promote the vaccination of children. The nurse from the PHC transports the vaccines in ice. The test shown in the image is performed for which of the given vaccines?
questions.solution:
The image shown is shake test that is used for the pentavalent vaccine, which is a freeze-sensitive vaccine.

The "Shake Test" is used to check whether freeze-sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to temperatures below 0°C.  Once it has been thawed, the vial of freeze-damage vaccine no longer has the appearance of a cloudy liquid but tends to form flakes that settle down at the bottom of the vial.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Freeze-sensitive vaccines:

  • Hepatitis B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV (Inactivated poliovirus)
  • DPT
  • TT
  • PCV

 Measles, Oral poliovirus vaccine, and Bacille Calmette-Guerin vaccine are not damaged by freezing.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old male presents with the following visual field defect. On shining the torchlight to the temporal half of the left eye, DLR is absent on the same eye and CLR is absent on the opposite eye. When light is shone on the temporal half of the right eye, DLR and CLR are present. The most likely site of the lesion is

DLR: Direct light reflex

CLR: Contralateral light reflex
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette showing visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia along with pupillary defect showing absent DLR and CLR when light is passed on defective half(which is temporal half of left eye) and presence of DLR and CLR when light is passed on normal half(temporal half of right eye) i.e Wernicke's pupil. Therefore, site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

Here, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means:

in the left eye, the nasal visual field is lost, and
in the right eye, the temporal visual field is lost.

It means left temporal and right nasal fibers are destroyed, which leads to right homonymous hemianopia. Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibers from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Other features of optic tract lesions:

  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.
  • Optic disc changes. Optic tract lesions produce descending type of partial optic atrophy.
  • Visual acuity is usually intact in the intrinsic lesions of optic tract. 

Optic tract lesions can occur due to pituitary adenomas (most common), craniopharyngioma, tumors of the optic thalamus, large aneurysm of superior cerebellar or posterior cerebral arteries, demyelinating diseases, and infarction.

Other options:

Option A: Lesions at the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which involves visual loss in the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This is not consistent with the patient's described symptoms.

Option C: Lesions involving lateral geniculate nucleus have normal pupillary reflexes, as fibres for pupillary reflexes from the optic tract are diverted to pretectal nucleus and do not reach the LGN.

Option D: Optic radiation lesions can also result in complete homonymous hemianopia  is produced when total fibres of optic radiations, are involved. Pupillary reflexes are normal and optic disc changes do not occur as the second order neurons synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN).

questions.text: During the clinical trials of the drug esomeprazole, the researchers labelled it as a ‘me-too' drug for omeprazole. Which of the following makes it a me-too drug?

choices.text: Similar rate and extent of bioavailability as omeprazole
Structurally different but has a similar therapeutic action
Structurally similar to omeprazole but slightly altered
Similar distribution to the body tissues relative to the plasma

questions.solution:
Esomeprazole being structurally similar to omeprazole with slight alterations makes it a me-too drug. 

A me-too drug is a drug that is structurally similar to a drug that already exists in the market. Esomeprazole is a stereoisomer of omeprazole and is eliminated slowly compared to omeprazole making it more effective. The mechanism of action, target, and adverse reaction profile are similar for both drugs. 

Other options: 
Option A- Drugs with similar bioavailability are called bioequivalent drugs. Omeprazole is eliminated faster than esomeprazole lowering its bioavailability. Therefore, these drugs are not bioequivalent. 

Option B- Drugs that are structurally different but have a similar therapeutic action are called therapeutic analogues. Since both drugs are structurally similar, they cannot be therapeutic analogues. 

Option D- Both omeprazole and esomeprazole have different volumes of distribution.

questions.text: A frail premenopausal female presented with a 6cm lump in the left breast with ipsilateral level 2 matted axillary nodes. Her biopsy reveals an ER, PR-positive tumour with signs of lymphovascular invasion. She is unfit for surgery. What is the preferred drug for hormonal therapy, and for how long?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen will be given as hormonal therapy in the premenopausal patient with an ER, PR positive, locally advanced breast cancer (TNM staging of T3N2a). The tumour size of 6cm, axillary lymph node positivity and histopathology showing lymphovascular invasion indicate a high risk for relapse therefore, the duration of the therapy would be 10 years.

Patients with locally advanced breast cancers (LABC) are managed by hormonal therapy when the patient is unfit for surgery. Hormonal therapy for breast cancer includes tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors like letrozole, anastrozole, and exemestane. In premenopausal females, only tamoxifen is used for 5 years(Option C). For patients with a high risk of relapse, like positive nodes, size > 5 cm, or lymphovascular invasion (cancer cells present within the endothelium-lined space of blood vessels and lymphatics), tamoxifen is prescribed for 10 years. 

In postmenopausal females, aromatase inhibitors(Options A and B) are used, which prevent relapse and increase overall survival. A bone density scan is necessary before initiating treatment as it is associated with the risk of fractures.

LABC is defined as a T3, T4, N1, N2, N3 disease without metastasis (stages IIIA, IIIB) and can be managed as follows:

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy → Surgery (breast conservation surgery/ mastectomy) → radiotherapy
  • ER/PR positive- hormonal therapy
  • Her 2 neu positive- Trastuzumab

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents to the casualty with fever, palpitations, and altered sensorium. On examination, you find the following signs. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice which makes it effective for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical image showing right upper eyelid retraction (Dalrymple's sign) suggests a hyperthyroid male and the clinical symptoms suggest development of thyroid storm. Propylthiouracil, the antithyroid drug of choice in this condition, inhibits deiodinase. 

Deiodinase is the enzyme responsible for peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

Propylthiouracil also inhibits thyroid peroxidase that oxidises iodide to iodine and incorporates tyrosine into thyroglobulin, forming thyroxine and triiodothyronine. The added inhibition of peripheral conversion makes it superior to other thioamides.

  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)

questions.text: A patient presents with intense exertional chest pain radiating to the neck. He notes that the pain lasts about 10-15 minutes and is not relieved by rest or by taking nitroglycerin. ECG was done and is shown below. Cardiac troponins are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given patient's presentation of exertional chest pain radiating to the neck, lasting 10-15 minutes, and unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerin with ECG showing ST depression and normal cardiac troponin suggests the diagnosis is unstable angina.

Unstable angina arises due to an imbalance in the myocardial oxygen supply-demand ratio. They present with characteristic features such as chest pain at rest, of recent onset, and lasting for more than ten minutes. It usually lasts longer or is more severe than previous episodes. (crescendo pattern). The pain is usually retrosternal and might radiate to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw. 

ECG may show new ST-segment depression in one-third of the patients. In unstable angina, there is no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, namely cardiac troponin I or cardiac troponin T. In other words, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis.

Other options:

Option B : Prinzmetal angina is less likely because chest pain typically occurs at rest and usually relieved by nitroglycerin. Additionally, It is also characterized by transient ST-segment elevations on the ECG during episodes of pain.

Option C: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, a component of ACS, presents with similar symptoms. In contrast to unstable angina, there are elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers.

Option D: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, occurs due to occlusion of a coronary artery by thrombus. Usually, these vessels are already affected by atherosclerosis. The chest pain may last for more than 30 minutes, associated with marked diaphoresis. The ECG initially shows ST-segment elevation, and usually develops Q waves later on. There is an elevation of cardiac biomarkers.

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is a characteristic feature of?
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia is a characteristic feature seen in severe cases of phenol/carbolic acid poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism. It is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anaesthetizes the nerve endings.

Clinical features include: Burning, and tingling followed by anaesthesia, headache, giddiness, tinnitus, Vomiting, diarrhoea, pain in the abdomen, Muscular spasms, convulsions, clammy, cold, and sweating body. Ochronosis is sometimes seen in chronic phenol poisoning wherein the phenolic metabolites pyrocatechol and hydroquinone get deposited in the cartilages and ligaments causing dark pigmentation.

 An image of the ochronosis is shown below:


The patient passes dark, smoky urine, which turns olive green on standing due to the oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. This is known as carboluria. This can progress to anuria in 48 hours.

An image of carboluria is shown below:


Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil can be done. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Note: Ochronosis is also seen in alkaptonuria, an inborn error of metabolism, in which homogentisic acid is deposited in the cartilage, ligaments, and fibrous tissues.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of corrosives

Corrosive Mechanism of Action Type of necrosis
Strong acids Hydrogen ions penetrate tissues and lead to cell death and eschar formation. This prevents further hydrogen ion penetration and protects against deeper injury. Coagulation necrosis
Carbolic acid Same as other strong acids, but also hardens the GI mucosa. Produces a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. Coagulation necrosis 
Oxalic acid Same as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis
Hydrofluoric acid Fluoride ions scavenge intracellular cations, such as calcium and magnesium and inhibit Na/K ATPase, disrupting cell membranes. This leads to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. Liquefactive necrosis
Strong alkalis Hydroxide ions easily penetrate tissues, leading to the dissolution of cell membranes. It is associated with deep tissue injury. Liquefactive necrosis

questions.text:
A middle-aged non-alcoholic male presents to the OPD with a history of fatigue and pruritis, icterus, hepatosplenomegaly, and markedly elevated ALP is suspected to have primary sclerosing cholangitis. Which among the following is the investigation of choice in this patient?

MRCP- Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography

ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde Cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for the patient with the given clinical history with a suspicion of primary sclerosing cholangitis would be MRCP.  

MRCP is diagnostic and reveals intrahepatic and extrahepatic beading, multiple irregular strictures, and dilatation, as shown below.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is the diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of the entire length of the biliary tree, causing strictures and obliteration of both intra and extrahepatic bile ducts. It mainly affects middle-aged men. Symptoms include fatigue and pruritus. On examination, there can be icterus, hepatosplenomegaly and markedly elevated ALP, indicating a cholestatic liver disease. This may lead to portal hypertension and liver failure.  

Diagnosis is principally based on the radiological findings. Characteristic cholangiography findings without choledocholithiasis or bile duct surgery suggest PSC.  
PSC has a close association with ulcerative colitis and is known for increasing the risk of colorectal cancer and cholangiocarcinoma in such cases.  
 
Other options:

Option A- Liver biopsy shows the characteristic periductal onion-skin fibrosis, inflammation and bile-ductule proliferation but is not the investigation modality of choice as it is an invasive procedure. It can be done when the radiological findings are equivocal.

Option B- ERCP is done when therapeutic intervention is planned and usually follows MRCP.

Option D- P-ANCA levels may be elevated in PSC, but it is non-specific and has minimal diagnostic significance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, working in the paper industry complaints of shortness of breath followed by cough with expectoration for 5 months, associated with low-grade intermittent fever without chills and weight loss. He is thought to have an occupational lung disease. This could have been prevented by

choices.text: Using a safer asbestos like chyrsolite
Exhaust ventilation to avoid silica dust
Injection of fungicidal agent on cotton dust

questions.solution:
The given case scenario of a worker in a paper industry with breathlessness and cough with expectoration and intermittent fever is suggestive of Bagassosis. It could have been prevented by increasing the moisture content of bagasse.

Bagassosis is an occupational disease of the lung caused by inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. The sugarcane fibre is now utilized in the manufacturing of paper, cardboard and rayon. It occurs due to thermophilic actinomycetes. The symptoms consist of breathlessness, cough, haemoptysis and slight fever. Initially there is acute diffuse bronchiolitis and there is impairment of pulmonary function.

If treated early, there is resolution of the acute inflammatory condition of the lung. If left untreated, there is diffuse fibrosis, emphysema bronchiectasis.

Prevention of Bagassosis:

  • Dust control : Dust suppression measures like wet process, enclosed apparatus, exhaust ventilation etc. are used
  • Personal protection : Personal protective equipment (masks or respirators with mechanical filters or with oxygen or air supply) may be necessary.
  • Medical control :Unitial medical examination and periodical medical check-ups of the workers are indicated.
  • Bagasse control: By keeping the moisture content above 20 per cent and spraying the bagasse with 2 per cent propionic acid, a fungicide, bagasse can be rendered safe for manufacturing use .

Other options:

Option B: Using a safer asbestos like chrysolite will be done in mining, milling, insulation industry where asbestosis is very common.

Option C: Exhaust ventilation is a dust control method which is done in all industries where dust is involved. For silica dust, it will be done in metal casting work, sandblasting, hard rock mining, stone cutting industries.

Option D: Injection of fungicidal agent on cotton dust is done in textile manufacturing industries where bysinossis is common.

questions.text:
An RBSK medical officer who has clear reason to suspect that a child is being sexually abused fails to report it to the appropriate authorities. What is the punishment for the same?

RBSK - Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram

choices.text: Penal erasure from state medical council registry
Imprisonment of up to six months and/or fine
Imprisonment of up to six years and/or fine
Warning notice from state medical council registry

questions.solution:
All suspected sexual offences must be reported to the police as a rule. Failure to comply with this mandatory provision of the POCSO Act can attract imprisonment for up to 6 months or a fine or both. 

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 considers all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years as children and protects them from sexual abuse. The offences and respective punishments in the provisions of this act are as follows -

Offence Punishment If aggravated
1. Penetrative sexual assault Imprisonment for 10 or more years; May extend for life with a fine. Imprisonment for 20 years or more; May extend for life with a fine, or with death.
2. Sexual assault without penetration Imprisonment for ≥ 3-5 years and fine Imprisonment for ≥ 5-7 years and fine
3. Sexual harassment Imprisonment for 3 years and fine  
4. Child pornography

Imprisonment for 5 years and fine; 

A subsequent conviction is liable to 7 years of imprisonment and a fine.

  

 

Penal erasure is done for serious professional misconduct. It is also referred to as the professional death sentence. It deprives the practitioner of all the privileges of a registered practitioner. Serious Professional Misconduct/ Infamous Conduct in professional respect is any conduct of the doctor that might reasonably be regarded as disgraceful or dishonourable.

questions.text: A patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is being subjected to detect polymorphisms. The procedure involves treatment with a restriction enzyme. As per the standard procedure, which of the following will be the next step?
questions.solution:
The technique for a patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy to detect polymorphisms with restriction enzyme is Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP), and the next step is southern blotting as it is a DNA sequencing technique.

RFLP is the variations of DNA sequences among people at sites that can be recognised by restriction enzymes. These enzymes identify the change and sequencing, which is palindromic, and cleave it. The DNA fragments of defined lengths, hence produced, are subjected to electrophoresis on an agarose gel followed by southern blotting.

This is used clinically for prenatal detection of genetic disorders with mutations like sickle cell disease, thalassemias, phenylketonuria in infants, and Huntington's disease. They can also be used to trace the source of the DNA sample to a particular individual.

The process of RFLP is shown in the image given below.

Other options: 

Option A- Northern blotting is used to demonstrate RNA.

Option B- Western blotting is a technique to identify proteins not nucleic acids. 

Option D- In-situ hybridisation involves denaturation of DNA and adding a probe for hybridisation, when this probe is tagged with fluorescent labels it is called fluorescent in-situ hybridisation.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman at 39 weeks of gestation with a history of classical cesarean section is admitted for delivery. During the second stage of labor, she is noted to have fetal bradycardia associated with some vaginal bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the fetal station which was previously at +2, is at -3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on clinical features such as bleeding, loss of fetal station, and fetal bradycardia is uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is when all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa) are disrupted at any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labour, manual removal of placenta, dilatation and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

Note: "Loss of fetal station" is used to describe a situation where the fetal head, which has previously descended into the pelvic cavity during labour, begins to move back up during labour. This can be indicative of issues such as fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion, or obstructed labour.

The given findings of increased BT and normal PT, aPTT is suggestive of Platelet aggregation disorders. Decreased CD41 and CD61 (Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa) is suggestive of Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disease which occurs due to inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa. There is normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin. Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukaemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: Prucalopride, a prokinetic used in adults with chronic constipation, is an agonist on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist, and 5HT4 is a G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) depicted in number 2.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are of two broad types based on structure and function- GPCR or metabotropic and ligand-gated or ionotropic receptors. 5HT3 serotonin receptor is ligand-gated. All other serotonin receptors are GPCRs.

As shown in the image, GPCR is a seven-transmembrane receptor, i.e. there are six loops (three intracellular and three extracellular) that cross the membrane seven times. The binding of a neurotransmitter produces a second messenger (cAMP in this case), which mediates its actions.

By stimulating 5HT4 receptors, prucalopride facilitates cholinergic transmission throughout the intestine, increasing oral-cecal time. It is contraindicated in patients with intestinal obstruction and perforation, obstructive ileus, inflammatory bowel disease, and toxic megacolon. Prucalopride does not seem to increase cardiovascular risks, unlike cisapride. 

Other Options:

Option A- Number 1 shows a ligand-gated ion channel that opens on the binding of a hormone, leading to either cellular depolarisation or hyperpolarisation. Acetylcholine is a hormone that acts on such a receptor, with its ligand-gated ion channel containing five subunits forming a central pore. 

Option C- Number 3 shows a tyrosine kinase receptor, which exists as a dimer. Upon hormone binding, these receptors activate their intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity and phosphorylate tyrosine residues on their cytoplasmic tails. This phosphorylation triggers a cascade of intracellular signals that results in transcription activation. The insulin receptor is a dimerised tyrosine kinase receptor. 

Option D- Number 4 shows a hormone that diffuses into the cell and interacts with a cytoplasmic or nuclear receptor. The resultant hormone-receptor complex attaches to the hormone response element of DNA and activates transcription. Thyroxine and steroid hormones utilise this mechanism.

questions.text: An elderly female is brought to the OPD with complaints of increasing forgetfulness and urinary incontinence. What additional symptom will lead to the suspicion of Hakim-Adams syndrome?
questions.solution:
An elderly female with complaints of increasing forgetfulness and urinary incontinence with an additional symptom of abnormal gait points to a diagnosis of normal pressure hydrocephalus, also known as Hakim Adams syndrome.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. It presents with the characteristic triad of: 

  • Urinary incontinence (wet),
  • Dementia (wacky),
  • Gait disturbance- Ataxic or apractic gait (wobbly).

Diagnosis by neuroimaging shows enlarged lateral ventricles consistent with hydrocephalus, accompanied by minimal cortical atrophy. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals normal parameters aside from elevated pressure, and the CSF tap test demonstrates significant symptom relief following fluid removal.

Management involves the placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt to drain excess CSF. This intervention effectively alleviates symptoms and helps restore normal intracranial pressure, improving the patient's neurological function.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected whiplash injury following a road traffic accident. Identify the ligament that would be most commonly injured in this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of probable whiplash injury and the ligament that would be most commonly injured in this condition is the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine marked as 4 in the given image.

Whiplash is a form of cervical acceleration-deceleration injury. There is hyperextension followed by flexion in the recoil. The main pathological features seen in these cases include the tear (strain) of the anterior longitudinal ligament and the capsular fibres of the facet joints in the spine. In some cases, the intervertebral discs may be damaged. Fracture is seen in severe cases only.

Anterior longitudinal ligament:

  • It is a strong band that extends along the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies
  • It extends from the basilar part of the occipital bone to the upper sacrum
  • It is attached to the anterior tubercle of C1 and the body of C2

Infantile whiplash syndrome: Child being gripped in a rough manner, between the perpetrator's hands and shaken, often resulting in subdural hematoma & intraocular bleeding in battered babies.

questions.text: A young primi at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. All of the following symptoms indicate progression to severe pre-eclampsia, except _______.
questions.solution:
All of the given symptoms would indicate progression to severe pre-eclampsia except thrombocytosis. Severe pre-eclampsia is associated with thrombocytopenia.

Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. It is characterized by the development of gestational hypertension along with increased urinary protein excretion (≥300 mg/day) after 20 weeks of gestation. Other symptoms suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Headaches - usually over the occipital or frontal region
  • Visual disturbances - These could include scotomas. These are due to spasms of retinal vessels following retinal infarction, occipital lobe damage secondary to vasogenic edema, or retinal detachment. 
  • Epigastric or right upper quadrant pain - This is due to hepatocellular necrosis, ischemia, and edema that stretches the Glisson capsule. This is usually seen along with elevated serum hepatic transaminase levels.
  • Sudden and generalized or persistent edema - Visible edema over the ankles despite rest, especially on rising from the bed in the morning hours, is pathological. 
  • Diminished urinary output
  • Fetal-growth restriction
  • Pulmonary edema

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is most likely to be associated with biofilm formation?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa causing lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients is associated with biofilm formation.

This biofilm provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects it against antimicrobial agents.

The following image shows pyocyanin of P. aeruginosa, the green pigment in left tube cultured on heart infusion soft agar medium. The aerobic bacteria grow only on the surface of the medium (forming whitish biofilm), and water-soluble green pigment diffuses down.

The following image shows P. aeruginosa with fluorescent pigment under UV-light on cetrimide agar-agar.

Cystic fibrosis:

  • It is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder caused by the presence of mutations in both copies of the gene for the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance or malfunction of antibacterial peptides, increased the availability of bacterial receptors, and reduced ingestion of pathogens by CF cells are the factors involved in chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis.

E. coli virulence is mediated by pili that extend from the bacterial cell surface and help mediate adherence to host cell surfaces.

questions.text: A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. Local examination showed a swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot, as shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute onset pain and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot suggests the diagnosis of acute gout. Losartan can be safely administered to this patient as it is a uricosuric drug.

Losartan is competitive angiotensin I (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 
  • Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption and actively secretes uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule

Adverse effects include fetopathic potential, hypotension, renal insufficiency, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta blocker that has been proven to increase serum uric acid levels; hence, it is avoided.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it is not used in patients with gout as it increases the uric acid level.

Option D: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hyperuricemia due to increased reabsorption of uric acid. It is not used in patients with gout.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with breathlessness following thyroid surgery. The laryngoscopy findings of this patient are shown below. The surgeon recommends a surgical intervention to improve the airway. Which type of thyroplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is experiencing significant airway obstruction due to bilateral abductor paralysis, characterized by the paramedian position of the vocal cords, as shown in the image. Thyroplasty Type II, also known as vocal cord lateralization, is the most suitable surgical option among the options. 

This condition often arises postoperatively, particularly following thyroid surgery, where the recurrent laryngeal nerves may be inadvertently damaged. Thyroplasty type II procedure aims to laterally reposition the vocal cords, thereby widening the airway and alleviating the patient's breathlessness. While it may compromise voice quality, the primary objective here is to restore adequate airflow.

Thyroplasty is a phono-surgical technique that aims to improve the voice/airway by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

  • Type I: Medialization of vocal cord
  • Type II: Lateralization of vocal cord
  • Type III: Shortening or relaxation of the vocal cord. This is done in puberphonia and in those who have undergone gender transformation from female to male.
  • Type IV: Lengthening or tightening of the vocal cord. This is done in androphonia, laxity of cord due to age and in those who have undergone gender transformation from male to female.

Note: MLSL - Medialization, Lateralization, Shortening, Lengthening

questions.text: A 2-week-old preterm infant presents with a history of blood in her diapers. Her PT and aPTT are prolonged, but platelets are normal. The intrinsic deficiency of which of the following produces these symptoms in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The 2-week-old preterm infant with blood in diapers with prolonged PT, aPTT and normal platelets is most likely suffering from haemorrhagic disease of newborn due to the intrinsic deficiency of Vitamin K produced by intestinal flora, i.e. menaquinone.

Vitamin K exists as three biologically active compounds- phylloquinone (dietary source in green vegetables), menaquinone (synthesised by intestinal bacteria), menadione, and menadiol diacetate are synthetic compounds that are metabolised to phylloquinone.

Newborns, especially preterm infants, lack intestinal flora for endogenous synthesis of vitamin K and, hence, solely rely on exogenous vitamin K. Breast milk is deficient in free vitamin K, which makes them prone to vitamin K deficiency. Maternal use of vitamin K antagonists like warfarin, phenytoin, and primidone can also cause severe haemorrhagic disease, causing severe systemic bleeding, ecchymoses in the 1st week of life with bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract, umbilical stump, nasal, or intracranial bleeding.

questions.text: A young man presents with persistent visual disturbances. He finds it difficult to see at night for the past few months. There is a tingling sensation in his upper limbs. On examination, the following finding is seen. This is due to defects in the:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with night blindness, tingling sensation, and progressive visual disturbances along with an image showing ichthyosis suggests Refsum disease. This occurs due to a defect in the alpha oxidation of phytanic acid in peroxisomes.

Refsum disease is a disorder of alpha fatty acid oxidation. It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years and is characterized by

  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Anosmia
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ichthyosis
  • Cardiac conduction defects
  • Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein levels, without an increase in cells (albuminocytologic dissociation).

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition. Treatment consists of dietary restriction to eliminate phytol-containing foods. A strict reduction in dietary phytanic acid intake is associated with a significant improvement in the symptoms.

Infantile Refsums disease is a distinct entity, which presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with features of parkinsonism and cerebellar features. An MRI brain was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI characteristically shows the pontine hot cross bun sign which is highly suggestive of multiple system atrophy.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease. Along with the features of Parkinson's disease, they also have cerebellar and autonomic features. The common autonomic feature seen in these patients is orthostatic hypotension. MSA is characterized by the presence of degeneration in the striatum, cerebellum, and inferior olivary nuclei coupled with characteristic glial cytoplasmic inclusions. These inclusions stain positively for α-synuclein.

It is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P: T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hypointensity due to iron deposition
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Other options:

Option A: Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring balance. 

Option C: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted vertical eye movements with downward gaze palsy. Patients also have hyperextension of the neck with gait disturbances and frequent falls. MRI may reveal characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with normal pons. This is called a hummingbird sign. There is degeneration of the striatum, subthalamic nucleus, midline thalamic nuclei, and pallidum, coupled with neurofibrillary tangles and inclusions that stain for tau protein.

Option D: Dementia pugilistica/punch drunk syndrome is post-traumatic dementia, not degenerative dementia. This occurs in boxers & football players after repeated head trauma over many years. It is characterized by emotional lability, dysarthria, and impulsivity.

questions.text: A patient presents with polydipsia and polyuria passing 10-12 l of urine per day. His urine has low osmolality and specific gravity and serum vasopressin is undetectable. The drug used in the management of this patient will not have therapeutic benefit in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: A child with primary nocturnal enuresis
A female with post lumbar puncture headache
A female with Type III Von Willebrand’s disease
A male with moderate factor 8 deficiency

questions.solution:
The patient with polydipsia and polyuria passing 10-12 l of urine per day with low urine osmolality and specific gravity and undetectable serum vasopressin levels has central diabetes insipidus, and desmopressin is used for the management of the patient. Desmopressin will have no therapeutic benefit in a female with Type III Von Willebrand’s disease (VWD).  

Desmopressin is a long-acting vasopressin analogue that is primarily used in the management of central diabetes insipidus. It is also used in patients with VWD type I (mild to moderate quantitative defect) by increasing the VW factor and shortening bleeding time. It is, however, not effective in VWD III (complete absence of VWF) and types IIa and IIb (qualitative defects and causes thrombocytopenia).

It can also be used in patients with mild to moderate deficiency of factor VIII in hemophilia A. Since it acts by increasing the factor levels,  it is not very effective in severe forms of these bleeding disorders.

Bedtime administration of oral desmopressin is used for children with primary nocturnal enuresis. The water retention ability and subsequent establishment of CNS fluid equilibrium make it effective in post-lumbar puncture headaches.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with thickened, discoloured, brittle nails, as shown below, that have worsened over several months. He mentions that he often goes to shared spaces without wearing any footwear. On examination, the distal edge of the nail is lifted with debris accumulation beneath it. What is the most common pattern observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of the affected nail, points to a diagnosis of Tinea unguium/onychomycosis and the most common pattern is the distal and lateral subungal type of onychomycosis.

Tinea unguium is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many other fungi may be causative.

Clinically, yellowish discolouration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described:

  • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - most common form
  • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
  • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  • Endonyx onychomycosis
  • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
  • Mixed onychomycosis

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

Mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis are treated topically with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine. 

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for onychomycosis. Oral Terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernail infection and 3 months (12 weeks)  for toenail infection. Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is the second-line drug.

questions.text:
An Rh-negative isoimmunised mother at 30 weeks of gestation with antibody titres of 1: 32 was found to have an MCA peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoM. The umbilical vein cordocentesis showed a hematocrit of 28%. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

MCA- Middle Cerebral Artery
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient is intrauterine transfusion of blood. 

Intrauterine blood transfusion via the umbilical vein is done when the period of gestation is < 34- 35 weeks and hematocrit is < 30%, as in this case. For patients with > 34- 35 weeks of gestation, termination of pregnancy is the management.

Blood type O negative, cytomegalovirus negative, with a hematocrit of 80% (to prevent volume overload), irradiated and leukoreduced (to prevent graft-versus-host reaction) is transfused after administering muscle relaxants to the fetus to reduce fetal movements.

The target hematocrit is 40-50% in non-hydrops fetuses, which can be achieved via multiple transfusions. The volume required is estimated by multiplying fetal weight in grams by 0.02. While monitoring the MCA doppler MSV, the cut-off becomes 1.7 MoM post-transfusion owing to the adult blood transfused.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby is being investigated for recurrent vomiting and failure to thrive. Laboratory tests reveal hyperammonemia and increased urinary excretion of orotic acid, uracil, and glutamine. The following disorder occurs due to defect at
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with recurrent vomiting and failure to thrive, hyperammonemia and increased urinary excretion of orotic acid, uracil, and glutamine is indicative of Type 2 Hyperammonemia or  ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency) which is marked "2" in the image.

Type II hyperammonemia results due to a deficiency of Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC). In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate which is channeled to pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased excretion of orotic acid. 

Clinical symptoms include vomiting, irritability and severe mental retardation. Mild forms show episodes of hyperammonemia, manifested by vomiting and neurologic abnormalities (e.g., ataxia, mental confusion, agitation). These episodes usually occur after ingestion of a high-protein diet or as a result of a catabolic state such as infection.

The laboratory findings during the acute attack are hyperammonemia accompanied by marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine. The blood level of urea is usually low. There is a marked increase in the urinary excretion of orotic acid. Diagnosis is confirmed by gene analysis.

Management includes treatment of acute hyperammonemia attacks. For enteral use, citrulline is used in place of arginine in patients with OTC deficiency. Liver transplantation is a successful treatment for patients with severe OTC deficiency. Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Other options : 

Option A : The enzyme marked "1" is Carbomyl phosphate synthetase 1 which is deficient in Hyperammonemia type 1.

Option C:  The enzyme marked "3" is Ornithine permease which is deficient in HHH syndrome (Hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria syndrome).

Option D: The enzyme marked "4" is Arginosuccinate sythetase which is deficient in Citrullinemia.

questions.text:
Four cases are pointing towards four different diagnoses. Which among the following does point towards an autosomal dominant disorder?

1. Recurrent pulmonary infections and failure to thrive in a child with salty skin and meconium ileus at birth.
2. Hepatic dysfunction, psychiatric symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in a young adult with low serum ceruloplasmin.
3. Muscle weakness with delayed relaxation after handgrip (myotonia), frontal balding, and cataracts in a young adult.
4. Progressive muscle weakness, Gower's sign, and calf pseudohypertrophy in a young boy, with elevated serum creatine kinase (CK).
questions.solution:
The correct clinical scenario that points toward an autosomal dominant disorder is "Muscle weakness with delayed relaxation after handgrip (myotonia), frontal balding, and cataracts in a young adult". This is suggestive of myotonic dystrophy, which is an autosomal dominant disorder.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused by to CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

Other options:

Option A: Recurrent pulmonary infections, failure to thrive, salty skin, and meconium ileus at birth – This is consistent with cystic fibrosis, which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option B: Hepatic dysfunction, psychiatric symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings with low ceruloplasmin – This describes Wilson's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option D: Progressive muscle weakness, Gower's sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK – This is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with sore throat and a wash-leather membrane over the tonsils. Which among the following culture media is used for rapid diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The 10-year-old child with a sore throat and wash-leather membrane over the tonsils has diphtheria and the culture media used for rapid diagnosis is Loeffler’s serum slope.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causing diphtheria can be isolated by culture on Loeffler's serum slope which is a medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint. 

Given below is the image of Loeffler's serum slope with c. diphtheria.

Other media like potassium tellurite agar, Mcleod’s, and Hoyle’s produce black-coloured colonies due to the reduction of tellurite to metallic tellurium. The growth of bacteria may take two days.

On gram stain, gram-positive rods with polymetaphosphate storage granules called Babes- Ernst granules or metachromatic granules give the bacilli a beaded appearance and are arranged in cuneiform arrangement. Neisser’s or Albert's stain shows green-coloured bacilli with purple-blue-coloured metachromatic granules.

The image below shows C. diphtheriae on Albert's stain.

BCYE (Buffered Charcol Yeast Extract) medium is used for nutritionally fastidious Legionella pneumophila.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with complaints of a painless lump in her right breast. USG showed the presence of a smooth-walled cyst without any solid component in its wall. What will be the BIRADS score and management of this patient?

choices.text: BIRADS 2, requires only observation without biopsy
BIRADS 3, requires biopsy to plan management
BIRADS 2, requires biopsy to plan management

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and ultrasound findings of a smooth-walled cyst without any solid component in its wall are suggestive of a simple breast cyst, which is classified as a BIRADS 2 lesion that requires only observation without biopsy.

Breast cysts are a type of ANDI ( Aberrations of Normal Development and Involution ) commonly seen as painless lumps between 35 and 55 years of age. A smooth-walled cyst without any solid component indicates a benign lesion and is classified as BIRADS 2, which requires only observation and follow-up annually.

Breast cysts can be multiple and bilateral and can mimic malignancy. A solid component in the cyst wall is indicative of a complex cyst, and a core biopsy should be done to rule out cystadenocarcinoma. A complicated cyst has intracystic floating debris, which moves with postural change and is classified as BIRADS 3 (probably benign). 

If the cyst is associated with pain or inflammation, the fluid is aspirated. If the cyst regresses totally or the aspirate is not blood-stained, no further treatment is needed. If there is a residual lump or if the aspirate is blood-stained, a core biopsy/excision is done. When the debris is infected, a short course of antibiotics is used for the management.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression. Ocular examination findings are shown below. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated transaminases and increased urinary copper excretion. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression with high urinary copper excretion and elevated liver enzymes is suggestive of Wilson's disease. The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring that occurs due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea. Low serum hepcidin is not associated with Wilson's disease, but rather with hemochromatosis.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia (option A).
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia (option D).
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with a decrease in the functioning of hepcidin. This leads to increased absorption of intestinal iron. There is a deposition of this excessive iron in parenchymal cells, leading to cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, bronze discoloration of the skin, congestive cardiac failure, hypogonadism, and arthropathy.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Trethowan's sign is seen in the x-ray and the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis.

In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by the Hilgenreiner’s line and the Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.
