questions.text: A middle-aged woman who underwent a surgery for neck swelling presented with the following sign in the postoperative period. Her medical history includes recurrent abdominal pain and renal stones. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the clinical finding of Trousseau's sign (carpopedal spasm) points towards hungry bone syndrome or hypoparathyroidism after a parathyroidectomy, whose typical features are:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hyperkalemia

Hungry bone syndrome occurs in patients with preoperative hyperparathyroidism who have increased bone breakdown. When a patient’s parathyroid hormone level drops drastically post-surgery, the stimulus to break down bone is lost. Hence, the bones are hungry for calcium and remove it from plasma rapidly.

It usually occurs after parathyroidectomy, thyroidectomy, or in prostate cancer patients on estrogen. Sudden cessation of the existing increased bone breakdown makes bones absorb calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus rapidly. 

Management includes correction of these factors and magnesium infusion. Bone ALP continues to rise in the first few weeks of treatment. Discharge medications should include Vitamin D and calcium supplements for 6 months. 

The scenario in this case is primary hyperparathyroidism, which is the 3rd most common endocrine disorder after diabetes and thyroid disease. Adenomas are more common than hyperplasia, and the former occurs mostly in the inferior parathyroid. It is common in middle-aged women. 

Clinical features include 

  • Painful bones - increased osteoclastic activity leading to von Recklinghausen disease / brown tumour, which is due to sub-periosteal bone resorption.
  • Renal stones - hypercalcemia leading to stone formation and calcified renal vessels cause renal hypertension.
  • Abdominal groans - hypercalcemia stimulates gastrin release, which causes peptic ulceration. It can also precipitate acute pancreatitis. 
  • Psychic moans - depression and anxiety as nonspecific symptoms.

Other features include skin necrosis, corneal ulceration, band keratopathy, pseudogout, constipation, polydipsia, glycosuria, etc., 

Investigations include serum PTH, phosphorus, calcium, bone density estimation, vitamin D levels, urinary calcium(>250mg/24 hrs), ALP(alkaline phosphatase), and radiological investigations like Xray skull showing salt and pepper appearance, Xray spine showing rugger jersey spine, USG abdomen to look out for other organs, USG neck, and CT. Thallium - Technetium scan shows hotspots (diagnostic of adenoma). TC-99m labelled Sestamibi scan is more sensitive than the Thallium-Tc scan.

Treatment includes surgical removal if the indications are met. Nonsurgical care involves good hydration, regular exercise, vitamin D and calcium supplementation, and estrogen therapy. Bisphosphonates and cinacalcet may be tried.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of hearing voices that are asking him to end his life for the past 3 weeks. He speaks in sentences that do not make complete sense. On further probing, he reveals that recently, he had witnessed losing his friend in an accident. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of auditory hallucinations and disorganized speech for the past 3 weeks in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event, a provisional diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder can be made. The presence of these symptoms for less than one month and a history of a traumatic event are the clinchers for this diagnosis. 

A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day and is followed by a complete remission within a month of the appearance of the symptoms. There may also be a precipitating stressor like a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, according to DSM-5, requires the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

According to ICD-11, this is classified as acute and transient psychotic disorder (ATPD), and the duration of the episode does not last for more than 3 months.

The diagnosis is usually anticipatory or retrospective, after ruling out other mental health disorders and substance abuse. Relapses are seen due to a lack of adherence to medication and should be monitored on a long-term basis. Management of the episode involves hospitalization and initiation of psychotherapy along with pharmacotherapy. Second-generation antipsychotics are considered the first-line treatment option, while benzodiazepines can be used to manage the symptoms in an agitated patient.

Other options:

Option A. When a manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia, with a minimum of 2 weeks of delusions or hallucinations without mood abnormalities, schizoaffective disorder is the appropriate diagnosis.

Option C. A diagnosis of Schizophrenia, which has a similar presentation of psychotic symptoms, requires the continuous presence of these symptoms for a period of at least 6 months.

Option D. Schizophreniform disorder differs from a brief psychotic disorder in that the symptoms have a duration of at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought to the hospital with poor head control,  hypotonia of the upper limbs, and delayed motor milestones. The mother gives a history of kernicterus in the baby during the early neonatal period. MRI scan of the brain revealed atrophy of the globus pallidus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a child along with MRI finding of atrophy of globus pallidus (in basal ganglia), most likely points to diagnosis of dyskinetic cerebral palsy. 

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a static encephalopathy affecting movement and posture due to non-progressive disturbances occurring in the developing fetal brain. The subtypes of cerebral palsy include:

  • Spastic diplegia
  • Spastic quadriplegia
  • Spastic hemiplegia
  • Dyskinetic cerebral palsy

Dyskinetic/Athetoid/Choreoathetoid/Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. Clinical features include hypotonia with poor head control. Hypertonia with rigidity and dystonia, involuntary movements can develop in the later years. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. MRI scan of the brain reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

Other options:

Option B- Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants due to damage to immature white matter. Periventricular leukomalacia is the most common neuropathologic finding in spastic diplegic patients. Below is the MRI image showing periventricular leukomalacia.

Option C- Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Option D- Spastic hemiplegia is associated with thrombophilic disorders and infections. MRI is more sensitive than CT scan for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. An intravenous urogram suggested the presence of a duplicated collecting system. Which of the following rules is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The Weigert-Meyer law is applicable in the case of duplicated collecting system.

According to the Weigert-Meyer rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter, the ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney. The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 

The upper ureter is considered ectopic and the lower ureter is considered orthotopic. Ectopic ureters are more prone to obstruction. Orthotopic ureters are more prone to reflux due to perpendicular entry into bladder musculature rather than oblique entry.

Other options:

Option B: The percentage of burns is calculated in a given patient according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Option C: Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Option D: Jenkin's rule for abdominal closure states that the length of the suture should be at least four times the length of the wound.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labor, has obstructed labor. Her uterus undergoes tonic contraction and retraction forming a ring. Which would best describe this ring?

choices.text: Chances of uterine rupture are less
It is not felt per abdominally

questions.solution:
Bandl's ring/Pathological retraction ring is formed in cases of obstructed labor. The statement that best describes it is that it moves progressively upwards.

In obstructed labor, the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction, while the lower segment dilates. With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter, while the passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

The thinned-out lower segment can ultimately give away and lead to uterine rupture. Thus chances of rupture is more. It can be felt abdominally but cannot be felt vaginally. Polarity is normal.

Other options correspond to constriction ring/Schroeder's ring.

Constriction ring/Schroeder's ring is formed due to incoordinate uterine contraction (abnormal polarity) when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM). The upper segment contracts and retracts with relaxation and the lower segment remains thick and loose.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. She has a history of persistent eye rubbing. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. All the following are treatment options for given condition except?

choices.text: Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-B radiation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lower lid bulging on downgaze (Munson's sign- as shown in the image) is suggestive of keratoconus. Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-A radiation (not UV-B), is a treatment modality for this condition.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Important associations:

  • Rigid contact lens wear
  • Chronic eye rubbing
  • Marfan's, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amaurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of the cornea (thinnest point) 

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lens
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitize the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature in an effort to improve vision
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal, with no immature cells. A lymph node biopsy is done and the findings are shown in the image below. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis?

TLC- Total leucocyte count

DLC- Differential leucocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 and BCL2 positive cells with image showing abnormal lymphoid follicles with centrocytes and centroblasts is highly suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center. 

The majority of follicular lymphomas have characteristic (14:18) translocation. This juxtaposes the IGH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to lymphoma cell survival.

Histopathology:

Lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - Small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - Large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

The peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis and the bone marrow tap reveals paratrabecular lymphoid aggregates.

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Other options - 

Option B - Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that mainly occurs in children and young adults. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 to chromosome 14 or 22 - t(8:14) or t(8:22). Histopathology of the tumor reveals a starry sky appearance. It usually presents with a mass involving the mandible and abdominal viscera. Immunophenotyping of the cells shows IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 positive and BCL2 negative.

Option C - Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Pautrier microabscess. Lesions include scaly, red-brown patches; raised, scaling plaques that may be confused with psoriasis; and fungating nodules. The presence of B-cell markers in the question rules out the differential of mycosis fungoides.

Option D - Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the presence of chimeric BCR-ABL gene which is a result of a reciprocal (9;22) (q34;q11) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome). The presence of lymphadenopathy in the given scenario rules out the possibility of CML as it is a myeloid disorder.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with a 1-month history of fever, non-productive cough, dyspnea, and a 1-year history of multiple joint pains and occasional bluing of hands. Cutaneous findings are given. On examination, she has proximal muscle weakness. Lab results show elevated CPK, with positive anti-Jo-1 antibodies. The most likely diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation of fever, non-productive cough, dyspnea, multiple joint pains, raynaud's phenomenon proximal muscle weakness, and elevated CPK levels, along with the presence of positive anti-Jo-1 antibodies and image showing cutaneous findings of mechanic’s hands suggests a diagnosis of anti-synthetase syndrome.

Anti-synthetase syndrome comprises of presence of myositis, nonerosive arthritis, ILD, Raynaud’s phenomenon, mechanic hands, and fever associated with anti-Jo-1 antibodies antibodies against aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. Individuals with anti-synthetase syndrome (AS) typically have elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, indicative of muscle inflammation. Those affected by interstitial lung disease (ILD) often show reduced forced vital capacity and diffusion capacity on pulmonary function tests. A spiral chest CT scan is the most effective way to detect the honeycomb pattern seen in ILD.

Muscle biopsy shows perimysial damage and perifascicular necrosis predominantly in contrast to dermatomyositis where there is perifascicular atrophy.

Other options:

Option A: Dermatomyositis typically presents with typical skin findings like facial erythema beyond malar distribution, heliotrope rash. over eyelids, gottron’s papules over knuckles and shawl sign over chest which are absent in this case. Autoantibodies more commonly seen in dermatomyositis are anti-Mi2, anti-MDA-5, anti-TIF1 and anti-NXP-1.

Option B: Polymyositis has no skin involvement or interstitial lung disease.

Option C: Inclusion Body Myositis usually affects older adults, involves distal muscle weakness, and does not present with anti-synthetase antibodies or lung involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, pirfenidone is the least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

Pirfenidone is a growth factor inhibitor. It inhibits growth factors involved in connective tissue proliferation.

Pirfenidone is used to manage acute exacerbations of pulmonary hypertension and to slow the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. Another drug with the same mechanism and use is nintedanib.

Side effects of pirfenidone predominantly involve the gastrointestinal system, nervous system, and skin. They present as nausea, diarrhoea, dizziness, fatigue, photosensitivity, and rash.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient was treated with haloperidol for delirium. He then developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, and muscle stiffness and showed agitation and an altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The abovementioned clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol are suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening adverse effect to antipsychotics with a predilection in males. Young patients are affected more commonly than elderly patients. Haloperidol poses the highest risk for NMS.

NMS is characterized by increased pulse and blood pressure; motor and behavioral symptoms such as muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, and agitation; and autonomic symptoms like hyperthermia. Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatine phosphokinase, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria.

The condition may occur within 24–72 hours after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Treatment includes the administration of dantrolene, bromocriptine, and sometimes, amantadine. Bromocriptine and amantadine pose direct DRA effects and may serve to overcome the antipsychotic-induced dopamine receptor blockade. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) has also been used for its management.

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, which can raise plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with symptoms in order of appearance - diarrhea, restlessness; extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, rapid fluctuations in vitals; myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity; and eventually delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is the most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol presents as a typical anaphylactic reaction with angioedema, facial and laryngeal edema, rash, urticaria, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

questions.text: A middle-aged man met with a minor accident, following which he developed difficulty in abducting his hip.  Which of the following is the most likely muscle to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle most likely to be affected in this case is the gluteus medius, which is responsible for the abduction of the hip joint.

The gluteus medius is a powerful abductor of the hip joint and is assisted by the gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, piriformis, and sartorius. Injury to the gluteus medius and minimus causes the sinking of the pelvis on the unsupported side when trying to stand on the affected limb (positive Trendelenberg sign). This produces a characteristic lurching gait.

Gluteus medius and minimus can be tested by medially rotating the thigh against resistance with the knee flexed.

Adduction of the hip joint is mainly caused by adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis.

Flexion of the hip joint is mainly caused by psoas major, iliacus, rectus femoris and assisted by pectineus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius.

Extension of the hip joint is caused by gluteus maximus, biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus (hamstrings), and adductor magnus and assisted by the posterior fibers of gluteus medius. 

Other options:

Option A - Gluteus maximus produces extension of the hip joint.

Option B - Quadriceps femoris consists of four muscles (rectus femoris, vastus medialis, vastus lateralis, vastus intermedius) and produces extension of the knee joint.

Option C - Quadratus femoris produces lateral rotation of the thigh.

questions.text: A bone marrow transplant recipient presents with fever, chest pain, productive cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture of the patient shows the following growth. Which of the following if detected in the serum is the marker for diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The bone marrow transplant recipient with fever, chest pain, productive cough and hemoptysis with sputum culture showing a dark green powdery or velvety growth on sabouraud agar is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis by Aspergillus fumigatus, and serum galactomannan is the marker for diagnosis in this condition.

Galactomannan is a component of the Aspergillus cell wall, and its presence in the serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of the patients is a marker for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. 

Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is a common complication of immunosuppressed individuals like bone marrow transplant recipients where neutropenia is induced. It presents as severe necrotising pneumonia with fever, new onset cough with hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain or pleural rub. Thrombosis and infarction of pulmonary vessels due to the invasiveness of the fungi leads to its systemic spread. 
HRCT shows dense, well-defined lesions with the characteristic halo sign, as shown below.

Sputum culture for the growth of Aspergillus or indirect tests for the detection of galactomannan can be done. The drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis is Voriconazole.

Other options:

Option A- Arabinogalactan is a polysaccharide that is a structural component of mycobacterial cell wall.

Option C and D-  Beta 1-3 glucan and chitin are both components of the fungal cell wall. They are present in other species of fungi as well and are not specific to Aspergillus..

questions.text: Which of the following muscles cause jaw retraction?
questions.solution:
Temporalis causes retraction of the jaw. 

Muscles of mastication: 

Temporalis: It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Medial pterygoid: It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

Lateral pterygoid: It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Masseter: It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted to the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of mandible/ closing of mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a positively/ right-skewed distribution where mean> median> mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode must be 11, 9, and 7 respectively. None of the other options have such a sequence.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positively or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

The mean in a positively skewed distribution is pulled up because of the relatively small number of very high scores. The mode is the most frequent and the highest point on the curve, while the median lies between the mean and mode. 

Other options:

Option A: Mean= median= mode is seen in a normal (unimodal) distribution.

Option C: Mean< median< mode is seen in a negatively skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with ventricular septal defect is posted for corrective surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child undergoing cardiac surgery, sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction.

Halothane and sevoflurane are non-pungent and are less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath-holding or laryngospasm during induction. Hence, halothane and sevoflurane are most suited for use in induction among pediatric patients.

Sevoflurane is less frequently associated with significant myocardial depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias which are seen with halothane. Hence, sevoflurane is preferred over halothane, especially in all cardiovascular surgeries in the pediatric age group.

Halothane sensitizes the heart to catecholamines, therefore careful reduction in the epinephrine dose in local anesthetic solutions must be followed. 

Following induction, isoflurane and sevoflurane are the most commonly used inhalation agents for maintenance. 

Desflurane and isoflurane are pungent compounds that irritate the airway and may lead to increased airway resistance, breath-holding, and laryngospasm which make them a poor choice for induction.

questions.text: A physician prescribes colchicine to a patient diagnosed with an acute episode of gout. By what mechanism does this drug improve his condition?

choices.text: Reducing neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue

questions.solution:
Colchicine acts by reducing neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and neutrophil adhesion. 

It arrests the cell division in G1 by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. Colchicine can also alter neutrophil motility and decrease the secretion of chemotactic factors and superoxide anions by activated neutrophils. 

Colchicine is considered second-line therapy in acute gout because it has a narrow therapeutic window and a high rate of side effects, particularly at higher doses. Adverse effects mainly involve gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Life-threatening toxicities are associated with the administration of concomitant therapy with P-glycoprotein or CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Allopurinol and Febuxostat decrease uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

Option B: Probenecid and lesinurad increase uric acid excretion by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid by organic anion transporters.

Option C: Aspirin, an NSAID (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drug), covalently acetylates the catalytic subunits of the COX-1 and COX-2 dimers, irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX) activity. Through this mechanism, the drug shows antipyretic, analgesic, and anti-inflammatory actions.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man had an NSTEMI 3 years ago and was lost to follow-up. He has now presented with dyspnea on exertion and pedal edema. On examination, he has an elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Which of the following drugs is not found to decrease the risk of mortality in him?

NSTEMI: Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction
JVP: Jugular venous pressure
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure secondary to NSTEMI. Digoxin is not found to decrease the risk of mortality in heart failure.

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The important etiologies of heart failure include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, high output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, and severe anemia.

Clinical features of heart failure include dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, pedal edema, anorexia, pallor, elevated JVP, ascites, and hepatomegaly.

Heart failure is classified based on the ejection fraction:

  • Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) - left ventricular ejection fraction is ≥50%
  • Heart failure with mid-range ejection fraction (HFmEF) - left ventricular ejection fraction 40-50%
  • Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrPF) - left ventricular ejection fraction is ≤40%

The mainstay management of heart failure is medical therapy and device therapy is reserved for refractory cases. The type of medications used in medical therapy are:

  • Drugs with symptomatic and mortality benefits provide symptomatic relief and reduce mortality risk by preventing cardiac remodeling. It includes - 
    • Angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) - a combination of sacubitril and valsartan
    • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors - ramipril, enalapril
    • β-blockers - metoprolol, carvedilol, bisoprolol
    • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist - spironolactone, eplerenone
    • Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitor) - dapagliflozin
  • Drugs with only symptomatic benefits provide only symptomatic relief and have no effect on reducing mortality risk. It includes - 
    • Loop diuretics - furosemide
    • Digoxin

Unfortunately, evidence of the clinical benefits of most therapies is restricted to HFrEF. Pharmacological therapy used in HFpEF is mainly diuretics.

Non-pharmacological therapy includes implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD), cardiac resynchronization using biventricular pacing, etc. These treatments are not found to be effective in HFpEF.

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, malaise, fatigue, and headache for the past 3 days. The peripheral blood smear examination is as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate resembling stereo headphones in appearance, are characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Hypnozoites are absent in P. falciparum infection.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, including but not limited to tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. 

The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Normal size RBCs
  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

questions.text: Houston's valves are the structures present in which part of the digestive tract?
questions.solution:
Three transverse mucosal folds (also known as Houston's valves) are commonly present in the rectum.

The transverse mucosal folds are permanent and become very prominent on distension of the rectum.

  • The superior transverse fold - present at either side of the beginning of the rectum and may occasionally encircle the entire lumen.
  • The middle transverse fold - largest and constant fold present above the rectal ampulla. It projects from the anterior and right wall of the rectum.
  • The inferior transverse fold - most variable and found on the left side.

Apart from these, the rectal mucosa has several longitudinal folds, which disappear on distension of the rectum.

questions.text: A multigravida woman who has an Rh-negative blood group delivered a baby with an Rh-positive blood group. The baby developed mild hemolytic anemia during 1st week of life. This reaction is an example of a___
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic anemia due to Rh incompatibility which is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In type II hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies (rarely IgM) combine with the antigenic determinants on the cell surface activating the complement system. This leads to complement-mediated lysis as seen in the above scenario.

Direct Coombs test is used to detect antibodies (from the mother) that are coated to RBCs. (Indirect Coombs also detects antibodies, but the serum is used as the sample)

Examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions: 

  • Transfusion reactions( ABO and Rh incompatibility)
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Goodpasture Syndrome
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Graves disease
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Pernicious anemia

questions.text: Risk of which of the following is not reduced with the use of antenatal corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Antenatal corticosteroids do not protect against meconium aspiration syndrome.

Antenatal corticosteroids reduce the incidence of

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)
  • Neurodevelopmental impairment
  • Overall neonatal mortality

They are given to mothers who are at risk of preterm delivery before 34 weeks. Intramuscular injections of either 2 doses of 12 mg betamethasone are given 24 hourly or 4 doses of 6 mg dexamethasone are given 12 hourly.

Contraindications include frank chorioamnionitis.
